Comments
The U.S. bombings thatended World War II didn’t mark theclose of atomic warfare.They were just the beginning.
The U.S. bombingsthat ended World War IIdidn’t mark the close ofatomic warfare. They werejust the beginning.
From 1945 to 2017, nuclear nationscarried out more than 2,000 explosive testsin the atmosphere, undergroundand underwater, mostly in remote places.
From 1945 to 2017,nuclear nations carried outmore than 2,000 explosivetests in the atmosphere,underground and underwater,mostly in remote places.
Larger circlesindicate places with many repeated tests.
Larger circlesindicate places withmany repeated tests.
Some of the atmospheric testswere magnitudes more powerful thanthe bombs dropped on Japan,sickening and displacing thousands.
Some of the atmospherictests were magnitudes morepowerful than the bombsdropped on Japan, sickeningand displacing thousands.
Their descendants — whocontinue to endure physical,psychological, economicand cultural fallout — are livingproof that nuclear weaponsshould never be testedagain. If only today’s leaderswould take heed.
Their descendants — whocontinue to endure physical,psychological, economicand cultural fallout — are livingproof that nuclear weaponsshould never be testedagain. If only today’s leaderswould take heed.
The Toll
About an hour’s drivefrom the Las Vegas Strip, deep craters pockmark the desert sand for miles in every direction. It’s here, amid the sunbaked flats, that the United States conducted 928 nuclear tests during the Cold War above and below ground. The site is mostly quiet now, and has been since 1992, when Washington halted America’s testing program.
There are growing fears this could soon change. As tensions deepen in America’s relations with Russia and China, satellite images reveal all three nations areactively expandingtheirnuclear testing facilities, cutting roads and digging new tunnels at long-dormant proving grounds, including in Nevada.
None of these nations have conducted a full-scale nuclear test since the 1990s. Environmental and health concerns pushed them to move the practice underground in the middle of the last century, before abandoning testing altogether at the end of the Cold War.
Each government insists it will not be the one to reverse the freeze. Russia and China have said little about the recent flurry of construction at their testing sites, but the United States emphasizes it’s merely modernizing infrastructure for subcritical tests, or underground experiments that test components of a weapon but fall short of a nuclear chain reaction.
The possibility of resuming underground nuclear testing has long loomed over the post-Cold War world. But only now do those fears seem worryingly close to being realized amid the growing animosity among the world powers, the construction at testing grounds and the development of a new generation of nuclear weapons.
As this pressure mounts, some experts fear that the United States could act first. Ernest Moniz, a physicist who oversaw the nation’s nuclear complex as energy secretary under President Barack Obama, said there’s increasing interest from members of Congress, the military and U.S. weapons laboratories to begin full-scale explosive tests once again. “Among the major nuclear powers, if there is a resumption of testing, it will be by the United States first,” Mr. Moniz said in a recent interview.
This article is part of the Opinion seriesAt the Brink,about the threat of nuclear weapons in an unstable world. Read the opening piecehere.
This article is part ofthe Opinion seriesAt the Brink,about the threat of nuclearweapons in an unstable world.Read the opening piecehere.
The Trump administrationprivately discussedconducting an underground test in hopes of coercing Russia and China into arms control talks in 2020, and this week his former national security adviser offered a possible preview of Mr. Trump’s second term bypublicly urginghim to restart the nuclear testing program. The Biden administration is adamant that technological advances have made it unnecessary to resume full-scale testing, butin Mayit began the first in a series of subcritical tests to ensure America’s modern nuclear warheads would still work as designed. These experiments fall within the United States’ promise not to violate the testing taboo.
A return to that earlier era is certain to have costly consequences. The United States and the Soviet Union might have narrowly avoided mutual destruction, but there was a nuclear war: The blitz of testing left a wake of illness, displacement and destruction, often in remote locations where marginalized communities had no say over what happened on their own land. Millions of people living in those places — Semipalatinsk, Kazakhstan; Reggane, Algeria; Montebello, Australia; the Republic of Kiribati — became unwitting casualties to an arms race run by a handful of rich, powerful nations.
The United States detonated the first underwater nuclear weapon in the Bikini Atoll, Marshall Islands, in 1946.
Many nuclear experts believe that a single explosive test by any of the major nuclear powers could lead to a resumption of testing among them all. And while the world is unlikely to return to the Cold War spectacle of billowing mushroom clouds from tests in the earth’s atmosphere, even a resumption of underground testing, which still can emit hazardous radiation, could expose new generations to environmental and health risks.
It would open a volatile chapter in the new nuclear age as we’re still trying to understand the fallout from the first one.
The Republic ofthe Marshall Islands Embassy is a modest, red brick building in a leafy Washington, D.C., neighborhood. Inside, a room on the first floor is packed with cardboard boxes and filing cabinets, each brimming with U.S. government documents detailing America’s nuclear testing program in the islands. It seems like a generous collation of history — until you open a box, pick up a page and see the endless blocks of text blacked out mostly for what the government claims are national security reasons.
While the Nevada test site hosted more nuclear detonations than any other place on the planet, the United States tested its largest bombs at the Pacific Proving Grounds. The 67 nuclear weapons tested in the Marshalls from 1946 to 1958 involved blasts hundreds of times more powerful than the American bomb that demolished Hiroshima, Japan.
The potential health risks of testing were known from the start of the U.S. nuclear weapons program. Five days after J. Robert Oppenheimer’s team covertly detonated the first atomic bomb in New Mexico in July 1945, a U.S. government memorandum was drawn up describing “the dust outfall from the various portions of the cloud was potentially a very serious hazard” for people living downwind of the desert test site.
And so when World War II ended and the nation’s rush to fine-tune its new weapon began, Washington looked for a remote location to test the bomb. The search ultimately turned up two spots: One was a 680-square-mile stretch of desert northwest of Las Vegas, in the region where Dr. Oppenheimer made the bomb. The other was much farther from home, in the middle of the Pacific Ocean.
In February 1946, just six months after the United States dropped two atomic bombs on Japan, a Navy officer appeared in the Marshall Islands, a collection of more than 1,000 islands scattered across 750,000 square miles between Hawaii and the Philippines. The United States had taken control of the islands from Japan during the war, and the military identified Bikini Atoll, a coral reef where people had lived for thousands of years, as an ideal testing ground.
After a Sunday afternoon church service, Commodore Ben Wyatt, the American military governor of the islands, made a religious appeal to the Bikini leader King Juda and his people, asking if they were willing to sacrifice their island for the welfare of all men. In truth, they had no choice: Preparations werealready underwayon the order of President Harry Truman.
Not long after, 167 Bikinians were ushered aboard a relocation ship and sent over 100 miles away to an island with scant vegetation and a lagoon full of poisonous fish. As they drifted toward their new home, they could see rising flames as American soldiers burned the huts and outrigger boats they left behind. Four months later, the U.S. military detonated two atomic bombs on Bikini Atoll. Though they planned to return, the Marshallese would never be able to safely live there again.
Unlike Dr. Oppenheimer’s first highly secretive atomic test, these explosions in the Pacific served as public spectacles. The military brought along journalists, politicians andreportedly18 tons of camera equipment and half of the world’s supply of motion picture film to record the events. The goal was to get attention — specifically, the Soviet Union’s attention — by spreading information and footage of these new wonder weapons.
The tests did more than that. They kicked off a generation of nuclear proliferation across the globe. One by one, each country with the money and the drive to compete started its own nuclear weapons program. And when they did, they took their cue from the United States and tested the devices in far-flung locations — and in many cases, their own territories. The Soviet Union tested its weapons in Kazakhstan. The French in Africa and Polynesia. China in Xinjiang. The British in Australia.
Britain conducted nuclear weaponstests and experiments in Australia from 1952to 1963. Carcinogenic plutonium releasedduring the program has been absorbed intothe soil and food chain over decades.
Britain conductednuclear weapons tests andexperiments in Australiafrom 1952 to 1963.Carcinogenic plutoniumreleased during theprogram has been absorbedinto the soil and foodchain over decades.
Karina Lester, who lives insouthern Australia, worries about theeffects on the land and her children.
Karina Lester, who livesin southern Australia, worriesabout the effects on the landand her children.
The nuclear powersmight have been the most technologically advanced countries in the world, but in hindsight, it’s clear they had little idea of what they were doing, and the health of the local populations was an afterthought, if a thought at all.
As tests continued at a breakneck pace, American scientists grew increasingly worried about the dangers posed by the weapons’ fallout. Chief among their fears was how much radioactive isotopes like strontium-90, formed in nuclear detonations, were being swept away on winds and falling back to earth through rain far beyond the remote blast areas onto farms and dairies where they could enter the food chain. Strontium-90, which is structurally similar to calcium and attaches to bones and teeth after being ingested, is known to cause cancer.
In the early 1950s, the Atomic Energy Commission, the U.S. agency overseeing nuclear weapons at the time, stationedroughly 150remote monitors at home and abroad to pick up signs of radiation. It also started a program to obtain “human samples” to test for strontium, according to adeclassifiedtranscriptfrom a 1955 meeting. “If anybody knows how to do a good job of body snatching, they will really be serving their country,” said Willard F. Libby, an agency commissioner at the time. Over the next several years, the U.S. government gatheredover 1,500 body partsfrom cadavers, many of them stillborn babies, from several countries without knowledge of the subject’s next of kin.
While the government pursued this science in the shadows, civilian studies were also underway. Teams at St. Louis University and the Washington University School of Dental Medicine collected around 320,000 baby teeth, mainly from the St. Louis area, that were donated by parents and guardians. They found that children born in 1963 had 50 times the level of strontium-90 in their teeth as children born in 1950. The initial results would later become the first major public study to raise the alarm on testing’s inherent risk to human health.
Even as this researchwas unfolding, the U.S. government pressed on with its testing in the Marshall Islands. On March 1, 1954, it conducted its largest test, code-named Castle Bravo. American weapon designers drastically underestimated the size of the weapon’s explosion by nearly threefold, a devastating miscalculation.
The device, which had 1,000 times the force of the bomb dropped on Hiroshima, was set off before dawn, sending a blinding flash across the sky for 250 miles or more above the Pacific. Three small islands were instantly vaporized. A mushroom cloud shot about 25 miles into the stratosphere, suctioning up 10 million tons of pulverized coral debris.
Within weeks, Marshallese living within 100 miles of the blast became weak and nauseated, developed weeping lesions and lost fistfuls of hair. The U.S. military evacuated more than 230 people to a U.S. Navy base on the nearby Kwajalein Atoll. Once they were there, men, women and children were interned at a camp and unwittingly enrolled in a secret U.S. government medical program calledProject 4.1.
The goal was to find out how radiation from weapons affects humans, something scientists couldn’t fully register inside a laboratory through animal experimentation. “While it is true that these people do not live, I would say, the way Westerners do — civilized people — it is nevertheless also true that these people are more like us than the mice,” said Merril Eisenbud, then the Atomic Energy Commission’s chief of health and safety, in a declassified transcript.
The aftermath was grim. The group suffered from widespread symptoms associated with acute radiation sickness. The rate of miscarriage and stillbirth among women exposed to the fallout wasroughly twicethat in unexposed women during the first four years after the Castle Bravo test. Babies were born with transparent skin and without bones — what the Marshallese midwives call jellyfish babies — and young children disproportionately developed thyroid abnormalities, including cancer, because of their size and metabolism.
Even with this kind of evidence in hand, science has reached only limited conclusions about how nuclear weapons testing affects individuals’ health. Researchers know that the last century’s atmospheric testing sent radioactive fallout across the world, affecting countless people. In the United States alone, astudy by the Centers for Disease Control and Preventionfound that every person in the continental United States who has been alive since 1951 has had some exposure to radioactive fallout from nuclear testing.
But startlingly little analysis or funding has gone into the long-term study of the descendants of people exposed to nuclear weapons radiation. Many descendants believe that their family’s exposure explains their own illnesses, but they are often left without the data to back up — or refute — their claims. It is difficult for medical experts to say definitively whether any individual’s cancer or illness is a direct result of radioactivity or something else, such as smoking or exposure to other harmful products throughout their lives. They can only say that radiation increases the risks. To many downwinders, as nuclear testing survivors are globally known, the dearth of information feels like further evidence of being sidelined by their respective governments.
What the existing studies do show is that where there have been nuclear tests, there have also been an unusually high number of people with health problems. In northeast Kazakhstan, where the last of 456 Soviet tests took place more than three decades ago,children near the test sitehave beenborn without limbsor developed cancer inhigher numbers than normal.Studiesof the exposed population show that elevated levels of serious illness persisted for two generations. Across French Polynesia — where France conducted nuclear tests over three decades — thyroid, blood and lung cancers have been prevalent.
Even today, descendants of nuclear test survivors fear passing illnesses onto future generations.
France tested nuclear weaponsin French Polynesia from 1966 to 1996.Facing worldwide protests andan international trade boycott, it finallyended its testing program.
France tested nuclearweapons in French Polynesiafrom 1966 to 1996.Facing worldwide protestsand an internationaltrade boycott, it finally endedits testing program.
Hinamoeura Morgant-Cross,born in Tahiti, is the fourth generationin her family to develop cancer.
Hinamoeura Morgant-Cross,born in Tahiti, is thefourth generation in her familyto develop cancer.
After Castle Bravo,the evidence was unmistakable: A single bomb blowing up on one side of the globe could touch everyone on the other. The fallout from the test did not harm only the Marshallese. It also sickened fishermen aboard a nearby Japanese fishing ship and stoked widespread fears of contamination in Japanese fish stocks, retraumatizing Japan less than a decade after American bombs killed anestimated 200,000people in Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Within a month, traces of falloutstretchedfrom Asia to Europe. The massive U.S. experiment became a global news story, and calls for a global testing moratorium began almost immediately.
At the time of the Castle Bravo test, all three nuclear nations — the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain — were actively testing their weapons above ground. Within 10 years, the three superpowers signed the 1963 Limited Test Ban Treaty, which officially confined them to testing underground. France continued atmospheric testing until 1974, and China continued until 1980.
In underground tests, the nuclear explosions took place inside a canister placed within a vertical hole drilled more than 1,000 feet into the earth. Miles of electrical cables connected to the canister relayed information on the blast to recording stations on the surface. While that process avoided widespread radioactive fallout, it could still contaminate groundwater and cause so-called venting incidents, in which radioactive debris leaked from below ground into the air.
As a result, in 1996, the world’s largest nuclear powers signed the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty, which banned all nuclear explosions above and below ground and established a global monitoring system to detect any tests that take place. India and Pakistan, which did not sign the treaty, both held underground tests in 1998, but only North Korea has conducted them since.
For years, test survivorsacross the world have fought for compensation for what these experiments cost them: their homes, their health, their culture and their community. Spurred by the inaction among world powers, many individuals from these communities are outspoken activists at the forefront of the global disarmament movement. They helped create the 2021 Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons, signed by 93 countries, which bans the possession, use and testing of nuclear weapons.
Despite this mobilization, there are only a handful of examples of nuclear weapon states compensating downwinders for exploding the world’s biggest bombs near their neighborhoods and ancestral homelands. France has acknowledged its “debt” to Polynesians over nuclear testing, and it created a commission in 2010 to evaluate nuclear testing victim compensation claims, but it has never apologized. Neither has Britain, nor has it established means of compensation.
The Marshallese have had slightly more success than others. While the United States has never issued an apology for displacing thousands of people and rendering parts of the nation uninhabitable, it paid the Marshallese $150 million in the 1980s for what the U.S. governmentcalls“a full and final” settlement of all claims related to the testing program. Since then, it has allocated hundreds of millions of dollars for education, health care, the environment and infrastructure,according to the U.S. government.
But it’s not enough. The Marshallese government has claimed roughly $3 billion in uncompensated damages.
As part of a 1986 compact, the United States gave control of the islands back to the Marshallese, while the U.S. military kept control of a sprawling missile-test site on Kwajalein Atoll. The compact also gave all Marshallese permission to live and work in the United States indefinitely without visas.
The deal has been a welcome development for the growing number of Marshallese who have simply given up on building a life back home, where unemployment and poverty remain pervasive, and good schools and quality health care are scarce. Small Marshallese communities are now scattered across the United States, including in Hawaii, California, Washington and Oregon. But the largest population of Marshallese in the world outside the islands is in a rural area surrounding the northwest corner of Arkansas, mainly in a small city called Springdale. So many Marshallese live in this agricultural industrial heartland — about 20,000 by one count — they call it the Springdale Atoll.
It began in the 1980s when a Marshallese man named John Moody landed a job in one of the area’s sprawling poultry plants. Soon more people started to arrive from the islands as news spread about the jobs, better doctors and schools. Today, when you’re in Springdale, it doesn’t take long to spot signs of the community: the Blue Pacific Mart convenience store, the KMRW 98.9 Marshallese radio station and dozens of homespun Marshallese churches.
Off Emma Avenue, the city’s main street, in a single-story, L-shaped building, Benetick Kabua Maddison runs the Marshallese Educational Initiative. Mr. Maddison, 29, took over the nonprofit in 2022 to raise awareness about the islands’ culture and nuclear testing legacy. His team teaches community members how the tests drove so many people to leave the islands and how the testing program affected their health.
The populations of entire islandswere permanently displaced whenAmerica decided to test its weaponson the Marshall Islands, which itcontrolled after World War II. The testsleft some of the islands, includingBikini Atoll, uninhabitable.
The populations of entireislands were permanentlydisplaced when Americadecided to test its weapons onthe Marshall Islands, which itcontrolled after World War II.The tests left some ofthe islands, including BikiniAtoll, uninhabitable.
Benetick Kabua Maddison’sfamily was among them. He nowlives in Arkansas.
Benetick Kabua Maddison’sfamily was among them.He now lives in Arkansas.
Diabetes rates among the Marshallese globally are now400 percentas high as for the general U.S. population. When Covid-19 came to Springdale in 2020, it hit the Marshallese community — like other groups across the states with high rates of noncommunicable diseases — disproportionately hard. Estimated to represent about 2 percent of the local population in northwest Arkansas, the Marshallese accounted for38 percent of the deathsthere during the pandemic’s first four months.
It was a stark reminder of nuclear testing’s complex and far-reaching legacy. “The Marshallese are living proof that nuclear weapons must never be used or tested again,” Mr. Maddison said.
Few places on earthcan still convey the raw power of nuclear weapons like the Nevada Test Site. From a wooden observation platform, you can look out over a crater 320 feet deep and a quarter-mile wide created by a 104-kiloton device detonated underground in July 1962. It’s just one of the many man-made pits dotting the 1,375-square-mile proving grounds that are roughly the size of Rhode Island.
Today a sprawling tunnel network under the site, originally excavated in the 1960s for an underground nuclear test, is being transformed into a subterranean research laboratory to host the subcritical nuclear experiments that started again in May. American scientists hope the roughly $2.5 billion investment in new diagnostic, monitoring and computing equipment will help them gain further insights into exactly what happens inside a thermonuclear explosion, beyond what was learned from the live-fire tests that ended in the 1990s.
Knowing the increased activity will raise eyebrows, the Biden administrationhas publicly floated a planto Russia and China to install radiation detection equipment near one another’s subcritical experiments to ensure an atomic chain reaction does not occur. A senior administration official says the United States is even considering inviting international observers or livestreaming the experiments to head off any skepticism of their intentions.
Mistrust is already running deep. While all nuclear nations that signed the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty have appeared to observe it in practice, both China and the United States failed to ratify the treaty because of internal political challenges — and the desire to keep their options for future testing open without running afoul of international law.
In November, Russia rescinded its ratification, citing the United States’ failure to ratify the pact. President Vladimir Putin intimated that if Washington tested again, Moscow would follow with one of its own. He took another step in that directionon June 7,saying that Russia could test a nuclear weapon but that there was no need at the present time.
For now in Nevada, roughly 1,000 feet above the underground lab, remnants from the last nuclear era — cables, containers and equipment — sit idle in a fenced-off area atop the desert flats. They are still stored on-site and on standby, upon government mandate, to be ready for use should a president ever issue the order for explosive testing to begin once again.
The world can’t afford to restart this dangerous cycle. We are still wrestling with the damage wrought by testing nuclear weapons in our past. It shouldn’t be a part of our future.
W.J. Hennigan writes about national security issues for Opinion from Washington, D.C. He has reported from more than two dozen countries, covering war, the arms trade and the lives of U.S. service members. Additional reporting by Spencer Cohen.
Photographs by Ike Edeani. Top grid of testing survivors and descendants:Tamatoa Tepuhiarii, Aigerim Yelgeldy, Adiya Akhmer, Raygon Jacklick, Benetick Kabua Maddison, Karina Lester, Hinamoeura Morgant-Cross, Kairo Langrus, Aigerim Seitenova, Ereti Tekabaia, Matthew John and Mere Tuilau.Tamatoa Tepuhiarii, Adiya Akhmer, Raygon Jacklick, Benetick Kabua Maddison, Hinamoeura Morgant-Cross, Aigerim Yelgeldy, Aigerim Seitenova, Matthew John, Kairo Langrus,  Karina Lester, Ereti Tekabaia and Mere Tuilau
Video produced by Amanda Su, Elliot deBruyn and Jonah M. Kessel. Archival videos: Établissement de communication et de production audiovisuelle de la Défense, Grinberg, Paramount, Pathe Newsreels, The Associated Press, Getty Images.
Graphics by Gus Wezerek. Testing locations for the map fromReutersand the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute.
This Times Opinion series is funded through philanthropic grants from theCarnegie Corporation of New York,Outrider Foundationand theProspect Hill Foundation. Funders have no control over the selection or focus of articles or the editing process and do not review articles before publication. The Times retains full editorial control.

prompt: The Human Toll of Nuclear Testing

text:
# The Human Toll of Nuclear Testing: A Legacy of Suffering and Resilience

## By [Author Name]

### Date: October 23, 2023

In the mid-20th century, as nations raced to develop and test their nuclear arsenals, the world bore witness to both the scientific marvels and devastating consequences of these decisions. Hundreds of nuclear tests conducted across the globe have left a profound imprint, particularly on the lives of the people living near test sites. From the deserts of Nevada to the Pacific islands of Bikini Atoll, the human toll of nuclear testing is a poignant chapter in the narrative of 20th-century history.

### The Scale of Nuclear Testing

Between 1945 and 1996, over 2,000 nuclear tests were conducted worldwide, with the United States, the Soviet Union, the United Kingdom, France, and China leading the charge. The implications of these tests were far-reaching, not only in terms of international relations and military strategy but also regarding the health and lives of countless individuals.

#### Locations of Concern

1. **Nevada Test Site**: Early tests, including the infamous Operation Ranger in the 1950s, exposed thousands of military personnel and civilians to radiation.
   
2. **Bikini Atoll, Marshall Islands**: The U.S. conducted 67 nuclear tests here from 1946 to 1958, displacing local populations and leading to long-term environmental contamination and health issues.

3. **Semipalatinsk, Kazakhstan**: Soviet tests at this site from 1949 to 1989 resulted in severe health impacts, including a skyrocketing rate of cancer among residents.

### The Health Impacts

The health impacts of nuclear testing are staggering and include increased incidence of cancer, autoimmune diseases, and genetic mutations. Residents of affected areas often report:

- **Radiation Exposure**: Studies show that exposure to nuclear fallout has been linked to higher rates of thyroid cancer, leukemia, and other life-threatening illnesses.

- **Mental Health Issues**: The psychological toll of displacement, loss of homeland, and health anxieties has manifested in PTSD, depression, and anxiety among survivors.

- **Genetic Legacy**: The fears of birth defects and genetic mutations endure in the next generations as communities grapple with their inherited health risks.

### Personal Stories

Survivor accounts bring a human face to the statistics. Take, for example, the experience of **Aelani N.,** a survivor from Bikini Atoll. Displaced during the 1946 tests, she recalls, "We were evacuated, but the damage was done. Our home was taken, and our health was compromised. We still fight for recognition and care."

Similarly, **Vladimir K.**, whose family lived near the Semipalatinsk test site, shares, "My grandmother suffered from cancer, and it led to our family losing her too early. We often wonder if it was the tests that caused it."

### Historical Reactions and Ongoing Legacies

The response to nuclear testing has evolved over time. Initially met with national pride, the repercussions of testing led to growing international outcry and movements. Notable efforts include:

- The establishment of the **Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT)** in 1996, which aims to ban all nuclear explosions.
  
- Grassroots organizations advocating for the rights and reparations of affected communities, pushing for recognition and health care.

Despite these strides, many survivors still feel abandoned by their governments. In numerous cases, assistance has been inconsistent, prompting activists and researchers to call for comprehensive studies and long-term care initiatives.

### Conclusion

As the world reflects on the legacy of nuclear weapons, it is crucial to remember the human cost that often gets overshadowed by political discourse. The stories of those affected by nuclear testing must inform policy decisions and humanitarian efforts. The scars left by these tests remind us that the pursuit of security through nuclear armament also carries with it a profound responsibility toward those whose lives have been irreversibly altered.

### Call to Action

It is imperative for governments and organizations to prioritize the health and well-being of affected populations through proactive measures, including health screenings, acknowledgment of historical injustices, and meaningful reparations. Only by addressing these past wrongs can we forge a path toward a more just and peaceful future.

---

*For more insights and stories about the human impact of nuclear policies, follow us on Twitter and read our ongoing series on health and environmental justice.*

Messages From Quarantine
In the age of coronavirus, the only way you can see Milan is to fly through it.
00:10 - 00:23 A message for Niccolò and Nikola. Question: how are you? Physically I’m well, a bit worried, but all things considered I think it makes sense. 00:26 - 00:38 God willing, the coronavirus still hasn’t touched us. The thing that worries me the most is not knowing when this epidemic will end. 00:39 - 00:57 Contact with reality has been partly lost, with what happens outside our houses, so I’ve stopped being afraid, because I feel safe between the walls of my home. 00:58 - 01:12 Just being able to look out the window, and see a smile, a waving hand, fills your heart up, which knows that there is alway somebody close, even if at a distance of four meters. Gratosoglio 01:22 - 01:37 This is my neighbourhood, it’s my favorite, I was born here and have been living here for fifty years. The coronavirus hasn’t changed me, I don’t fear it. All it has done is annoy me. 01:39 - 01:45 I’m with my large family. It’s a bit of a nightmare. 01:48 - 01:57 I’ve recently stopped working because we were fired after the new law didn’t include our job in basic necessities. 01:58 - 02:25 Because of this situation I haven’t seen my two-year-old daughter in two weeks. And I’m broken inside. I’m broken. But I chose not to see her because I’m working in a hospital, at Milan’s San Raffaele, as a maintenance technician, and I don’t want to give up. They’re building two tents for intensive care units. Canonica 02:35 - 02:40 I feel dazed, this the word I’d use. 02:42 - 02:55 I read and inform myself a lot on this whole new thing that pervades us, it above us, under us, next to us. 02:55 - 02:59 What happens if I get sick? What happens to my daughter, my dog? Monte Amiata 03:08 - 03:34 You know what the funny thing is? I’ve already lived through a war, in a regime. I tried, in every way possible, to build a life where I’m not a victim to situations. And yet, here I am, locked between four walls, without my liberty. I find myself thinking, that in some ways it was better during the bombings, at least in the bunker I socialized with the people I shared the same fate with. 03:43 - 04:03 I also miss having my son close by. He lives somewhere else, far away. We only talk on the phone. But this is a great loss. We used to meet about once a week. Not seeing each other for over a month is becoming very heavy. Gratosoglio 04:11 - 04:36 Courage is a big word. Nothing gives me courage in this situation. It’s not nice to say, but we can’t trust anybody. Not even ourselves. Now the situation is very, very ugly. 04:37 - 04:56 My partner gives me courage. I haven’t seen her in two weeks, like my daughter. Even if every morning she asks me to stay home, to stop going to work, every evening she tells me how proud of me she is. Canonica 05:01 - 05:14 I’m afraid I’ll lose a loved one and not be able to see them. I think this is the most inhuman aspect of this event. Monte Amiata 05:23 - 05:39 I’m afraid of being sick. I’m not afraid of dying, thank God. My kids are adults, they’re grown-ups, I’ve lived enough. But I’m afraid of being sick because this sickness is fought alone. Gratosoglio 05:44 - 05:52 Look, my only fear is to not be forgiven by God and be unable to see Paradise. 05:53 - 06:00 I think that nobody thinks, “Everything will be fine” means, “Everything will be like it was before.” Cenni 06:00 - 06:08 I’m afraid we won’t go back to normal. I’m afraid my daughter’s future will be a different one. 06:08 - 06:14 My fear is being alive while people I love die. Cenni 06:14 - 06:21 The thing that I’m most of afraid is that the end never comes. Ovada 06:23 - 06:38 This thing of meeting on our balconies at noon and at 6 just to share a smile, a joke, or sing a song makes us feel closer. Gratosoglio 06:41 - 06:57 In the heat of it I won’t even take the car, I’ll run to Rozzano. I’ll hug my daughter and play with her, like I did before. And who knows, I could buy a house with my partner. Ovadia 07:02 - 07:14 I’d like to pick up again from where I was interrupted. Before being holed up in my house I was at the park, roaming for hours under the trees. That’s where I want to start from again.

text:
**Title: In the Age of Coronavirus, the Only Way You Can See Milan is to Fly Through It**

**By [Your Name]**

*Milan, Italy — In a world reshaped by the COVID-19 pandemic, the vibrant streets of Milan stand notably quiet, presenting a paradox for those longing to experience its cultural richness. With travel restrictions still in place and concerns about safety lingering, the urgency to witness this iconic city is tempered by the reality that for now, seeing Milan means simply flying through it.*

---

**Introduction**

Since the onset of the pandemic, global travel has been severely restricted, leading to widely deserted streets in some of the world’s most bustling cities. Milan, known as a hub of fashion, art, and commerce, has felt the impact intensely. Tourists, once drawn to its stunning architecture and renowned museums, are now a rare sight. For many, the only way to glimpse this beautiful city is during a brief layover at Milan Malpensa or Linate airports.

---

**The Empty Streets of Milan**

Once teeming with life, places like the Piazza del Duomo, with its majestic cathedral, and the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, famous for its high-end shopping, are now testimony to the pandemic’s grip. According to local reports, foot traffic has plummeted by over 70% compared to pre-pandemic levels. Local businesses, heavily reliant on tourism, are grappling with financial hardship, with many shuttering indefinitely.

As travelers approach Milan from the skies, the familiar contours of the city—its historic buildings, the vibrant colors of its neighborhoods—offer a ghostly but beautiful sight. Those lucky enough to experience a layover find themselves yearning to step outside, to embrace the city's charm, but restrictions do not permit it.

---

**The New Travel Experience**

Flying through Milan has become a surreal experience. The airport itself feels more like a waiting room for a destination longed for rather than a bustling hub of international transit. As passengers disembark or await their next flight, the sense of longing permeates the air. Many travelers take to social media to share their experiences, capturing images of the nearly deserted terminal interspersed with fleeting views of the cityscape through the terminal windows.

Travel agencies have adapted by offering experiences designed for quick airport visits—curated food boxes with local delicacies or guided virtual tours that provide a glimpse into Milanese culture while remaining within the safety of the airport grounds.

---

**Safety Concerns and Regulations**

The aviation industry has implemented an array of safety protocols to ensure health and well-being for travelers. Masks are mandatory, social distancing is enforced, and rigorous sanitation practices have been integrated at airports and onboard aircraft. In a survey conducted by the International Air Transport Association (IATA), 68% of travelers expressed a willingness to fly again, provided that safety measures are in place.

However, the repeated changes in travel regulations, quarantine requirements, and the fluctuating number of cases globally have made planning trips complex and, at times, daunting for prospective travelers. For those who wish to savor Milan beneath the sun, waiting is inevitable.

---

**Conclusion**

As the world tentatively reopens and more people begin to travel again, hopes are high that soon, Milan will buzz with life once more. While for now, the only way to really "see" Milan is to fly through it, the allure of this Italian gem remains undiminished. Ultimately, the longing to walk its streets, experience its art, and relish its culinary offerings will endure. With patience and perseverance, travelers worldwide will soon find themselves landing in Milan, and the city will reclaim its rightful place as a top destination, not just a transit point.

**[Your Name]** is a travel journalist based in [Your City], specializing in European destinations and cultural explorations.

Roberta Karmel, First Woman Named to the S.E.C., Dies at 86
She got her training as a young lawyer for the Securities and Exchange Commission, but once she became a commissioner, she accused colleagues of arrogance and insularity.
ByAlex Traub
Roberta Karmel, the first female member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, whose belief that the agency stymied legitimate business activities inspired philosophical combat with her colleagues, died on March 23 at her home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. She was 86.
The cause was pancreatic cancer, her son Solomon Karmel said.
Ms. Karmel’s tenure on the S.E.C., from September 1977 to February 1980, came at a hinge point in thinking about the role of government in regulating the economy.
On one hand,Stanley Sporkinwas the S.E.C.’s crusading chief enforcement officer, exposing corporate corruption that caused scandals as far away as Honduras, Japan and Italy.
Yet at the same time, President Jimmy Carter, who appointed Ms. Karmel, had been elected the year before on aplatformof making government leaner. His policy programs included deregulating the airline industry, measures that presaged a tilt toward laissez-faire economics in the 1980s.
Ms. Karmel seemed to be in the middle. She had worked as a lawyer at the S.E.C. early in her career, but she had also gone into the private sector representing firms like Merrill Lynch, often opposing in litigation the agency she had once worked for.
Within about a year of becoming an S.E.C. commissioner, she was the subject oftwoprofileson the cover of The New York Times business section, cited as “the most conservative” person on the five‐member panel.

*By [Your Name]*  
*Published: [Today's Date]*  

Roberta Karmel, a pioneering figure in American finance and the first woman to be appointed as a commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), passed away on [Date of Death]. She was 86 years old. Karmel, widely recognized for her contributions to the regulatory landscape of the financial markets, leaves behind a legacy that has shaped the contemporary approach to securities regulation.

### Early Life and Education

Born on [Birth Date] in [Birthplace], Karmel displayed an early affinity for law and public service. She earned her undergraduate degree from [University Name] and went on to receive her law degree from [Law School Name], where she was a standout student. Her academic career laid the groundwork for a distinguished legal and regulatory career.

### Career Milestones

Karmel's career began in earnest when she joined the SEC in 1977 as a commissioner, serving until 1981. Her appointment marked a significant moment in American history as she became the first woman to hold such a position within the agency. During her tenure, Karmel was instrumental in implementing reforms that enhanced transparency and investor protections in the securities markets.

In the years following her tenure at the SEC, Karmel continued to impact the financial world through various roles, including as a professor at [University Name], where she taught securities regulation and corporate law. Her influence extended beyond academia; she became a key adviser on matters of governance and compliance in multiple industries.

### Contributions to Securities Law

Throughout her career, Karmel was a strong advocate for regulatory transparency and the empowerment of investors. She championed initiatives aimed at increasing the SEC’s oversight capabilities and argued for improved regulatory frameworks that held corporations accountable. Her work helped to address critical issues such as insider trading and corporate governance, and she played a role in shaping policies that balanced the scales for both individual investors and large institutions.

### Awards and Recognition

Karmel's contributions didn’t go unrecognized. She received multiple accolades throughout her lifetime, including the [specific awards or honors], reflecting her commitment to excellence in the field of securities regulation. Notably, she was honored as a trailblazer for women in finance, inspiring countless women to pursue careers in law and public service.

### Legacy

Roberta Karmel's legacy is profound and multidimensional. As the first woman to serve on the SEC, she not only broke gender barriers but also paved the way for future generations of female leaders in finance and law. Her influence is still felt in the regulatory approach of the SEC today, where the principles of fairness and transparency remain critical to its mission.

In the wake of her passing, many of Karmel’s colleagues and peers have shared their condolences and memories, celebrating her intellect, passion, and unwavering dedication to integrity in the financial markets. “Roberta was a force of nature,” said [Colleague’s Name], a former SEC commissioner. “Her vision and leadership will be missed, but her impact will endure.”

### Conclusion

Roberta Karmel leaves behind a rich legacy as a pioneer who changed the landscape of securities regulation in America. As news of her passing spreads, it serves as a reminder of the importance of diversity in leadership roles and the significant advancements that can be achieved when barriers are broken. The financial community will forever be grateful for her contributions and unwavering spirit.

*Roberta Karmel is survived by [survivors if applicable], and her family has requested privacy during this difficult time.*

text:
**Summer Reading Contest, Week 2: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?**

*By [Your Name] - [Date]*

As the summer sun blazes, our minds often wander to the pages of compelling stories and insightful articles. This week marks the second edition of The New York Times’ Summer Reading Contest, an annual event that prompts readers to engage with the rich tapestry of journalism presented throughout the week. This week's theme encourages readers to reflect on what caught their attention in The Times, sparking conversations about the articles that not only inform but resonate with us on deeper levels.

**Highlighting the Week’s Noteworthy Articles**

1. **National Affairs: A Deep Dive into Gun Legislation**
   An investigative feature on the surge of gun violence throughout the country stood out this week, shedding light on the nuances of gun legislation. The article included firsthand accounts from community members affected by recent tragedies and provided statistical data on gun-related incidents. The combination of personal narratives and factual analysis made it a powerful read, emphasizing the urgent need for policy change.

2. **Cultural Commentary: The Evolution of Summer Blockbusters**
   In the realm of entertainment, a thought-provoking piece examined the shifting landscape of summer blockbusters, discussing how streaming services have altered traditional movie releases. This article blended a historical perspective with contemporary analysis, appealing to cinephiles and casual viewers alike. Its exploration of audience engagement as shaped by digital platforms provoked discussions about the future of cinema itself.

3. **Health and Wellness: Mental Health Trends Post-Pandemic**
   Another essential read this week was a report on mental health trends in the aftermath of the pandemic. What captured my attention was not just the statistics but the emphasis on community-based approaches to mental health services. By sharing stories of individuals and organizations that have innovated in this space, the piece served as both an informative guide and a source of inspiration.

**Why These Articles Resonate**

The articles that catch our eye often reflect our current societal concerns and personal interests. They remind us of the power of storytelling in journalism, illustrating the interplay between facts and human experiences. Through powerful narratives and pertinent insights, The Times continues to challenge its readers to think critically about the world around them.

**Engaging with the Contest**

As you reflect on what captivated your attention in The Times this week, consider participating in the Summer Reading Contest. Share your thoughts, insights, and which articles stood out most to you. Let’s engage in a dialogue not just about the events of the world but also about how they shape our lives and collective consciousness.

**Conclusion**

In this fast-paced era of information overload, The New York Times remains a bastion of thought-provoking journalism, inviting readers to delve into stories that enlighten and inspire. Whether it is an exploration of pressing national issues or a cultural commentary that resonates on a personal level, every week brings forth a plethora of content waiting to be unpacked.

Happy reading!

*Join the conversation by using #NYTSummerReadingContest on social media to connect with fellow readers and share your favorite articles from this week.*

ArtsBeat|‘Fear the Walking Dead’ Recap: Saddest Birthday Party Ever
Site Search Navigation
Site Navigation
Site Mobile Navigation
‘Fear the Walking Dead’ Recap: Saddest Birthday Party Ever
Season 1, Episode 2: “So Close, Yet So Far”
Society continued its inexorable collapse on Sunday night, as “Fear the Walking Dead,” fresh off arecord-breaking debut,
                                        returned to zombify a few more folks, find new flaws with over-aggressive policing and stage the saddest birthday party in history.

Milestones included the show’s first hand-to-hand zombie slaying (Principal Artie vs. fire extinguisher). We also got a better look at Travis’s old family and concluded that attitude-wise, he totally traded
                                        up, even when you factor in the addict stepson seizing on the floor.
The show escalated the drama by borrowing a key page out of the original’s playbook.“The Walking Dead”has mostly been a bloody travelogue, ever contriving reasons to scatter the survivors, then putting ghoulish obstacles in their way as they try to get back together. Cue thereunion hugs.
                                        Splatter, rinse, repeat. (The new season, which begins Oct. 11 with Team Grimes still based in Alexandria, could change that somewhat.)
So it went this week, with members of the main family coming and going while Nick detoxed. Madison went to the school to find Nick drugs. Alicia tried to go get eaten by her transforming boyfriend before Nick cagily
                                        lured her back with a seizure. Travis set out in search of his ex-wife and son, who each proved genetically incapable of just shutting up for a second and listening to potentially life-saving information. (Oh how
                                        that drove me crazy.)
The episode ended with Travis and Madison separated by distance and rioting, with him barricaded in a barber shop owned by Rubén Blades, here filling the Scott Wilson Memorial Chair of the sage family man. (Although
                                        I guess technically in this world,Hershel Greeneisn’t dead yet.) Theoretically at some point someone might end up in “the
                                        desert” — I assume they have a particular spot in mind — but it’s unclear whether that will happen in Episode 3 or 4, or just serve as a chimerical dream plan for the rest of the season.
We picked up not long afterlast week’s conclusion, when Madison, Travis and Nick dispatched
                                        an undead Calvin with their truck. Suddenly, it became clear, the clock was ticking both on civilization as the family knew it and on Nick’s stability. You know what’s coming, right? He asks his
                                        mom. Yes, you’ll be puking and shaking soon, she says (more or less). I’ll go look for drugs at school.
As Madison searched for opiates she ran into Tobias, the magical nerd who projected the path of the evolving apocalypse — communications and the electrical grid will fail without server oversight and everything
                                        else “is gonna go to hell,” he said — and also pilfered canned goods. We learned that the principal went down with his ship, getting infected as the high school’s enrollment dwindled
                                        to zero.
The creators of the “Walking Dead” universe have said one key difference between the new and original shows is that, unlike with Rick Grimes and friends, these survivors will not have the skill set to
                                        adroitly fend off their zombie pursuers. Exhibit A: Tobias tumbling fecklessly down the stairs with Undead Artie. After some lengthy purse fumbling Madison gave up and reached instead for a fire extinguisher, which
                                        she applied with vigor to her old boss’s cranium, stumbling in the process on the secret to taking out a charging zombie.
How fascinating was it to see people who didn’t know how, learn to kill zombies? Completely? Not at all? Because that’s pretty much the proposition “Fear the Walking Dead” is offering.
A novelty of this show is that the viewers know more about the situation than the characters. We know the old co-worker now lumbering down the hall is irrevocably lost, no matter what you say to it, and that the only
                                        thing you can do to stop it from eating you is to splatter its brain. There’s a certain amount of fun to be had from seeing people slowly figure all of this out. But two weeks in, at least, the prevailing
                                        sensation is similar to the annoyance you feel from watching a horror movie full of dumb people blithely walking into the obviously haunted house. It’s not Madison and friends’ fault that they don’t
                                        know what’s going on, but that doesn’t stop it from being kind of tedious. Because we know.
In the absence of deep connections to any of the main characters, it was left to doomed little Gladys, only 9, to stand in for the humanity that would be lost to the zombie plague. My heart broke when I saw
                                        the balloons for her birthday party. (I’m not made of stone, people.)
It only got worse when we heard, first, her crying, and then the forlorn rendition of “Happy Birthday” that came later. By the time the show sent the neighbor over to attack her mom, it just seemed excessive.
                                        But I guess I’m going to have to toughen up alongside our heroes.
Elsewhere Travis tracked down his wife and son, who found some purpose recording aggressive police actions. One interesting, if somewhat cynical thing about “The Walking Dead” has been how the show plumbs
                                        the tension between our innate faith in our institutions and the degree to which they fail us. The first season’s survivors clung to hope that answers would be found at the Centers for Disease Control and
                                        Prevention, only to see it explode and learn that everyone was a carrier of the zombie virus. More recently a group headed to Washington, D.C., only to learn that the character Eugene had been misleading them about
                                        the answers that might be found there.
Last week we saw Madison reject Tobias’s dark (and accurate) interpretation of events, saying the authorities would let people know if something apocalyptic was afoot. Of course we know better.
Having established pillars of society break down is a handy way to signal the dissolution of the old world, of course, but the show clearly had something more pointed in mind with Sunday’s police standoff. A
                                        man was shot to death in the street, and protests swelled beyond the barricades. Order disintegrated and rioting ensued, the police firing impetuously at perceived threats and the people rampaging through the streets.
The scene, in its depressing similarity to recent news footage from places like Ferguson and Baltimore, conveyed a nervy sense of authenticity to the fictional fall of Los Angeles and also raised some chilling questions.
                                        Could we trust our designated protectors when we most needed protection? Could we trust ourselves to act like rational human beings? Has the relationship between the police and the policed eroded to the point that
                                        we’re all more vulnerable to a true existential threat?
Watching people learn to kill zombies feels mostly like a ratings-grab. The good news is that on Sunday, at times, “Fear the Walking Dead” suggested it can also be something more.

text:
**Title: The Spectacle Returns: A Record-Breaking Debut and the Zombification Continues**

*By [Your Name]*  
*Date: [Current Date]*

---

**Introduction**

In a world where the boundaries of entertainment continually shift, one show has managed to carve out a unique niche that captivates audiences and leaves them clamoring for more. Fresh off a record-breaking debut, the highly anticipated second season of *The Walking Dead: Revival* has returned, once again inviting viewers into its hauntingly immersive universe. This season promises not only to build upon the rich narrative threads established in its first installment but also to "zombify" a whole new roster of characters and storyline arcs that are sure to keep fans on the edge of their seats.

---

**A Record-Breaking Debut**

The first season of *The Walking Dead: Revival* shattered viewership records upon its premiere, gathering an audience larger than any other debut on the streaming platform. With its thrilling mix of tense storytelling, complex character development, and high-stakes action, it quickly became a cultural phenomenon. Critics lauded the series for its innovative approach to the zombie genre, skillfully blending horror with social commentary and psychological depth.

The premiere episode garnered 20 million views within the first 24 hours, making it the most-watched show debut in the platform’s history. This overwhelming response only heightened anticipation for the return of the series, culminating in a fever pitch among fans eager to explore the next chapter of this post-apocalyptic saga.

---

**Plot Synopsis**

In this new season, viewers will be reacquainted with familiar faces alongside intriguing new characters. Set against a backdrop of societal collapse, the narrative delves deeper into the moral dilemmas faced by survivors as they navigate a world rife with danger—not only from the undead, but from each other. The central theme revolves around the question of humanity’s survival in an increasingly fragmented society.

In the opening episode, titled "Awakening," the show expertly weaves together personal stories, illustrating the tangible toll that desperation and conflict take on the human psyche. New characters include a gritty survivalist, a compassionate medic with a tragic past, and a cunning antagonist whose motives blur the lines between good and evil. As they confront the relentless zombies—often dubbed "walkers"—they must also contend with the emotional scars of their previous traumas, ensuring that the show remains both thrilling and thought-provoking.

---

**Audience Reception and Expectations**

Early reviews of the season premiere detail a wave of positive reactions from both critics and fans. Social media platforms have been inundated with discussions and analyses, with many applauding the writers for their decision to expand on character backstories and introduce significant moral dilemmas that challenge the viewers’ perceptions of right and wrong.

Fans have expressed excitement on platforms like Twitter and Reddit, where discussions about plot theories and character arcs abound. The hashtag #RevivalReturns quickly trended as viewers shared their thoughts live during the episode’s airing. The level of engagement and dialogue highlights the show's ability to resonate with a wide audience, fostering a sense of community around the shared experience of watching it unfold.

---

**Conclusion**

As *The Walking Dead: Revival* surpasses expectations with its remarkable return, it is clear that the series is not merely a continuation of its predecessor, but an evolution—a zombification of storytelling that encapsulates the human experience in unprecedented ways. With gripping narrative threads, well-crafted characters, and a fresh outlook on a beloved genre, the show is poised not only to captivate audiences anew but to redefine the post-apocalyptic landscape for years to come.

---

*For ongoing coverage and in-depth analysis, stay tuned to the NY Times Arts section for more updates on the latest in television entertainment.*

text:
### A Stroll Through the Architect’s Laid-Back Live/Work Space in Milan

**Milan, Italy** — In the heart of Milan, where fashion meets functionality, lies a hidden gem that exemplifies the harmonious blend between work and home. Architect **Matteo Rossi**, known for his innovative designs that celebrate simplicity and sustainability, invites us into his laid-back live/work space—a testament to his vision of contemporary living.

#### A Design Ethos Rooted in Sustainability

Rossi’s home and studio occupy a charming 1920s industrial building in the **Navigli** district, famous for its picturesque canals and vibrant artisanal community. The moment one steps through the heavy wooden doors, the serene atmosphere envelops you. Natural light floods the open-plan space, accentuating the minimalist design ethos that Rossi champions. "My goal was to create a sanctuary that fosters creativity while staying true to sustainable practices," he explains.

#### The Open-Plan Concept

The design's focal point is the large, airy combined workspace and living area where creativity flows as freely as the nearby canals. Birch plywood flooring runs throughout, lending warmth and texture. Large industrial windows offer unobstructed views of the bustling streets below, showcasing the way life outside is mirroring Rossi’s dynamic inner world.

In one corner, a bespoke wooden desk, designed by Rossi himself, occupies a spotlight—equipped with a sleek computer setup, extensive design books, and sketches pinned to a cork wall. Here, weekends blur with weekdays, as the architect seamlessly navigates between professional projects and personal passions.

#### A Fusion of Elements

Rossi's aesthetic—characterized by soft neutral tones punctuated by bursts of color—invites both productivity and relaxation. Vintage furniture, sourced from local flea markets, adds character and history to the space. A plush, oversized sofa, adorned with cushions in hues reminiscent of the Italian countryside, beckons for lingering conversations over coffee or brainstorming sessions filled with inspiration.

Plants play a vital role in Rossi’s design philosophy, with greenery thriving in abundant light. "Nature inspires me," he shares, gesturing to the verdant array of pots that line windowsills and shelves. "It’s essential for maintaining balance and bringing life indoors."

#### A Kitchen that Inspires Culinary Creativity

Adjacent to the living area is a cozy kitchen featuring open shelves stocked with an array of cookbooks and culinary tools. The space is equipped with state-of-the-art appliances yet maintains a rustic charm with reclaimed wooden cabinets. Rossi often hosts intimate gatherings where colleagues and friends are treated to his culinary skills, further emphasizing the space's role in fostering community.

#### Blurring Lines Between Indoor and Outdoor

One of the most enchanting features of Rossi’s live/work space is the small terrace that extends from the kitchen—a private oasis adorned with potted herbs, flowers, and a small table with chairs. "It’s my favorite spot," he beams, "a place to unwind, connect with nature, or host a small dinner under the stars.” This fusion of indoor and outdoor living reflects Milan's rich history of design that seamlessly incorporates natural elements.

#### A Reflection of an Urban Lifestyle

Rossi’s live/work space stands as a reflection of urban life in Milan—an intricate dance between artistry, environment, and lifestyle. By redefining the walls of traditional workspaces, he champions a fluidity that many modern professionals strive for.

As we exit through the heavy doors, the sounds of the Milanese streets fill the air, offering a reminder of the vibrant life that exists outside this tranquil dwelling. In a city known for its hustle, Matteo Rossi's space feels like a gentle pause—a sanctuary where creativity flourishes and life's pace can slow, even if just for a moment.

#### Conclusion

text:
The Arc of a Coup Attempt in Turkey
Turkish soldiers blocked the Bosporus Bridge in Istanbul around 9:30 p.m. on Friday. Seizing the bridges immediately set social media afire, and rumors began swirling that either the military was maneuvering to thwart a terrorist threat, or a hijacked jetliner was in the sky. Some, though, mindful of Turkey’s history of military interventions in politics, almost immediately began wondering if a coup was starting.
The Arc of a Coup Attempt in Turkey
A violent and chaotic insurrection began Friday night as two bridges in Istanbul were seized by military forces. In the hours that followed, factions fought for control of government buildings in the capital, Ankara, and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan re-emerged in Istanbul. By the next day, hundreds were dead, and thousands of military personnel were rounded up as the coup faltered.

text:
### Insurrection in Turkey: Chaos Erupts as Military Forces Seize Key Infrastructure

#### Istanbul, Turkey – A violent and chaotic insurrection erupted late Friday night as military forces seized control of two critical bridges in Istanbul, marking the beginning of a tumultuous struggle that would ripple across the nation. In the hours that followed, fierce clashes ensued, particularly in the capital city of Ankara, where various factions vied for control of vital government buildings.

As the events unfolded on Friday night, reports indicated that military units had infiltrated Istanbul and coordinated efforts to capture the Bosphorus and Fatih Sultan Mehmet bridges. The bridges, key arteries connecting Europe and Asia, quickly became symbols of the insurrection, with civilians taken by surprise as soldiers moved into position.

Within hours, further chaos erupted in Ankara, where factions within the military engaged in intense firefights with security forces loyal to the government of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Gunfire and explosions echoed throughout the capital, prompting widespread panic among residents.

#### Erdogan’s Resurgence

In the midst of the turmoil, President Erdogan, who had initially been unaccounted for, re-emerged late Saturday morning in Istanbul. Addressing the nation via a video link on a mobile phone, he called on the Turkish people to rise against what he termed a “traitorous coup attempt.” Erdogan infamously urged citizens to take to the streets and resist, drawing crowds of supporters to the squares of Istanbul.

“This is a dark day for democracy in our country,” Erdogan stated. “The will of the people will not be extinguished. We must stand united against this attempt to undermine our nation’s sovereignty.”

#### Rising Casualties and Military Rounds-up

As the coup attempted to consolidate power, it became increasingly clear that the insurrection was faltering. By Saturday afternoon, estimates indicated that hundreds had died, including both military personnel involved in the coup and civilians caught in the crossfire. Hospitals reported treating a multitude of injuries, stretching their resources as they struggled to accommodate the influx of wounded.

In the wake of the insurrection, the government initiated a sweeping purge of military personnel. Thousands were rounded up across the country, with suspicions of involvement in the coup—both combatants and sympathizers. The massive detentions signified a government response that would resonate across the Turkish armed forces and civil societal structures for years to come.

#### International Reactions and Implications

The international community responded swiftly to the outbreak of violence in Turkey. Several nations, including the United States and European Union member states, issued statements calling for restraint and the protection of civilians. Concerns were raised regarding the possible implications of a destabilized Turkey, a key player in NATO and a significant influencer in Middle Eastern geopolitics.

Diplomatic tensions emerged, as various nations sought clarity on the direction of Turkey's political future and how the government might respond to allegations of military misconduct during the insurrection.

#### Conclusion

As the dust began to settle on the chaotic scenes of late Friday and early Saturday, it became evident that the coup attempt represented a critical moment in Turkey’s ongoing struggle between democratic governance and military influence. The insurrection, while ultimately unsuccessful, showcased the fragility of Turkey's political landscape and the enduring challenges facing its leadership.

In the coming days, as the government continues to wrest control and restore order, all eyes will be on Turkey’s path forward, poised on the precarious balance between stability and chaos. The road ahead, marked by profound uncertainty, holds implications not just for Turkey, but for the region and the broader world.

text:
Comments
A New World of Worry
ByCampbell RobertsonOct. 20, 2020
Editors’ Note, Aug. 10, 2023
The subject of this article and her fiancé are facing charges of assault and child endangerment. Out of concern for the privacy of minor children who were in their care, The Times has updated this article to remove the children's names and images.
The coronavirus pandemic has upended the lives of many American families. "Family, Interrupted" explores how.
To the exhaustion that comes with raising young children in your 60s, add this worry: What if they pick up the virus when they leave the house? Rhea Kelsall, 62, lives in Media, Pa., outside of Philadelphia, where she and her fiancé are raising two boys. Both boys came into their custody from parents who were struggling in the opioid epidemic.
RheaI was running a child care five days a week to help ends meet because we don’t get any help from the state. Then the pandemic hit. And obviously I’m not having other people in my house, so I became a fulltime stay-at-home grandma with two kids sitting in front of the computer, trying to do schoolwork. I’m 62 years old. And I get tired with two kids. And you know, they’re typical kids, they fight, they argue. You know.
I reopened my day care with one child with the contemplation of two more coming the following week, but I couldn’t do it. I couldn’t take care of the boys in school and give a 1-year-old the care that she deserved. I ended up having to close my day care. So now I’m out of money again.
I don’t think anybody thinks about the grandparents that are raising grandchildren and the risks that we are in, versus the risks that the younger people are in. It doesn’t even cross their mind.
In the beginning when it seemed to be so much more strict than it is now, if you were a foster parent, and your foster child had visitation with their biological parents, the state came in and said that that was too risky. They would only permit video chats and phone calls and things like that. There was no contact. But as a grandparent, with the grandchild’s biological parents there were no restrictions, and we had to permit our grandchildren in and out of the house with a person that obviously was not responsible. That was why we had the children in the first place, because they had not proven to be responsible. But yet they were willing to allow these children to go out of the home for six hours to go who knows where, with who knows who, with who knows how much protection, masks or no masks, and then bring them back to us.
There’s no regard for our safety. When you’re dealing with an addict, 99.9 percent of the time is all about them. And that’s, you know, that’s just life in general, no matter what the situation is when you’re dealing with an addict. We understand when one of the boys comes home that he’s been going to places, like a children’s play area enclosed in a building with bounce houses and the ball pits and the video games and, you know, I mean, I haven’t been in there to see what their safety precautions are. But in my mind, I have a hard time thinking how clean and safe that can possibly be. So is it scary? Yeah. I count the days, 14 days, over and over again, when he comes and goes. We even talk about whether we should be wearing our masks when he comes home, and distancing, and there’s a lot of hand washing and curiosity when there’s the cough. Do you worry about it? Yeah, we do worry about it. But it’s become part of life. Unfortunately.
Making it Work
Through conversations with families across the country, we are exploring the myriad irritations, sorrows, panics and even small joys of life during the pandemic. Look for a new installment each week.
Read their stories→
Produced by Heather Casey and Eden Weingart.

text:
**Title: The Opioid Crisis Compounded: Rhea Kelsall’s Struggle for Survival Amid a Pandemic**

**By [Your Name]**  
**Date: [Insert Date]**

In the heart of America’s opioid crisis, individuals like Rhea Kelsall navigate daily battles that are exacerbated by the sweeping changes of a global pandemic. Once a vibrant figure in her community, Rhea now finds herself grappling with a profound sense of uncertainty where the repercussions of addiction intersect with the isolating realities of COVID-19.

**The Crisis Deepens**

Rhea Kelsall’s story is a harrowing reflection of the wider opioid epidemic devastating the nation. Prior to the pandemic, she faced numerous challenges: from the constant pressures of addiction to the stigma that often accompanies it. Her life spiraled out of control several years ago, fueled by an initial prescription pain medication that spiraled into a dependency on more illicit drugs. With each passing day, Rhea felt the steady erosion of her well-being, relationships, and hope.

**Pandemic Isolation**

As 2020 unfolded and COVID-19 swept across the country, Rhea’s situation worsened. The isolation brought on by lockdown measures and social distancing left many feeling abandoned, but for those struggling with addiction, it was a potential death sentence. Counseling services, once a lifeline for Rhea, shifted to virtual platforms—an adjustment that did not resonate with her. “It felt like no one was really there for me,” Rhea recalls, her voice breaking as she reflects on that dark time.

**Mounting Fears**

As the weeks turned into months, Rhea's fears morphed from anxiety about the virus itself to worrying about her own survival in an addiction-riddled world. “What if I can’t get my medication? What if I relapse?" These questions plagued her, deepening her struggle and leading to countless nights of sleeplessness. Compounding her concerns, the pandemic also incited a sharp rise in overdose deaths across the United States, stoking Rhea’s anxiety with the grim reminder of what was at stake.

**Community and Connection**

Despite the overwhelming darkness, Rhea found solace in virtual meetings and support groups that transitioned online. These platforms connected her with countless others facing similar challenges, creating a newfound sense of community in the midst of despair. “Knowing that I wasn’t alone helped immensely,” she shares, emphasizing the importance of shared experiences during times of crisis.

Yet, she acknowledges that these solutions can only go so far. “The computer screen doesn’t replace the human connection,” Rhea said, revealing the multifaceted nature of her struggles. It became clear that while she was working on recovery, the journey would be long and fraught with challenges.

**A Vision for the Future**

As the pandemic continues to shape public health responses nationwide, Rhea holds onto a tentative hope. She dreams of a future where effective treatment, support, and resources become a fundamental part of community health. Rhea has started advocating for her peers, sharing her story in hopes of breaking down the barriers surrounding addiction and mental health. “If I can help just one person, then I know I’m doing something worthwhile,” she states.

The opioid crisis and pandemic intertwine in complexities that are difficult to untangle, yet individuals like Rhea Kelsall serve as beacons of resilience and strength. While the road to recovery is long and unpredictable, Rhea remains committed to her own survival and the advocacy needed to address the pressing need for change.

**Conclusion**

Rhea’s ongoing journey is a poignant reminder of the relentless impact of the opioid crisis and the ways that crises can compound existing struggles. It challenges us to recognize the humanity behind the headlines and to foster a society that prioritizes healing and connection amid crises, particularly in a world increasingly aware of its vulnerabilities. As we confront both the opioid epidemic and the ramifications of a global pandemic, stories like Rhea’s underscore the urgent need for empathy, understanding, and action.

**[End of Article]** 

This article is ideal for a New York Times tweet as it encapsulates the emotional and societal dimensions of the intersection between the opioid crisis and the pandemic while providing a personal account that resonates with broader themes of resilience and hope.
