The New York Times
ArtsBeat|Merritt Wever on the ‘Nurse Jackie’ Series Finale and Zoey’s Final Line
Site Search Navigation
Site Navigation
Site Mobile Navigation
Merritt Wever on the ‘Nurse Jackie’ Series Finale and Zoey’s Final Line
Spoilers for Sunday’s “Nurse Jackie” series finale follow.

The last time Edie Falco was in a series finale, viewers were left hanging over the fate of her TV husband, Tony Soprano. This time, it was her turn, as the title character in Showtime’s “Nurse Jackie”
                                        wrapped her seven-season run lying on a hospital floor after having apparently overdosed on drugs. Whether she lives or dies isn’t clear.
“I don’t think all shows need to have a wrapped-up ending,” said Merritt Wever, who starred alongside Ms. Falco as ebullient nurse Zoey Barkow. “But I thought this was an honest, appropriate
                                        and somehow satisfying ending. That’s the most you can hope for.”
Ms. Wever discussed the finale, which included the surprise reappearance of Jackie’s best friend, Dr. Eleanor O’Hara (Eve Best, who left the series in 2013). These are edited excerpts of the conversation.
What was the mood like on the set during the final season?
Over the course of the season, it wasn’t like everybody was morose. We were all very grateful, honestly. But the last few days were really sad.
In the scene when Zoey says goodbye to Jackie, were any of those tears real, or was it all just masterful acting?
There was probably a little bit of both, to be honest. I’d be lying if I said I wasn’t overwhelmed. I remember going home after that and realizing that was the last time I was going to get to act with
                                        Edie — how amazing it was that was part of my life for so long but just how much I was going to miss it. That never got old or lost its luster.
How was it having Tony Shalhoub join the cast for the last season?
It was great. He’s a lovely presence and actor to have around every day. I was really glad he got to be a part of the show, even at the tail end. And I liked how the writers had so many endings happening simultaneously
                                        during the last season: the hospital closing, Coop (Peter Facinelli) leaving, and Tony’s character losing his life. I thought that was appropriate.
What did you make of your final line, “You’re good, Jackie. You’re good”? Do you see a double meaning?
Yeah. In the first episode, Jackie said, “Make me good, God. But not yet.” In my mind, Jackie doesn’t make it. I think the ending is honest. And I’m glad that it’s not my responsibility
                                        to figure out what happens after the lights go out.
Have you given any thought to what happens with Zoey? The last we hear, she’s heading to Haiti to work with Doctors Without Borders.
I thought that was a lovely idea. She’ll always love Jackie and she’ll miss her a lot. That’s all I know about her future.
Why did she feel like she needed to break away from Jackie? Did she need to find her own path, or did she know on some level Jackie would never get clean?
It’s hard when you’re used to playing certain roles with somebody to break out of that emotionally. In the last season, Zoey had a hard time doing that in this new position professionally. I don’t
                                        see her ever being able to fully remove herself from that. And all good things must come to an end.
What did you think about Zoey’s evolution as a character? It’s mentioned that she started out in bunny scrubs and ended up as head nurse.
I was lucky that in the pilot, she shows up and she’s brand new. She had a long way to travel. I was glad she never lost her enthusiasm, confidence and zest for life. The writers were able to keep those things
                                        and still have her mature in her life.
So you were satisfied with the way it ended?
I was hoping I would be able to experience all the gratefulness without any of the sadness of having it end. That didn’t really work out. I loved Zoey so much, and the writers and Edie were so good to me. The
                                        only downside is that it may be the best job of my life. It’s all downhill from here.
Did you take home any mementoes from the set?
I took home my ID badge. The picture was taken on the first day of the pilot. I’m all fresh-faced, and I’m actually wearing the bunny scrubs. I’ve had the same badge since Day 1, so it’s
                                        pretty weathered.
What’s next for you as an actress? Would you do another TV series right away?
I don’t know. One of the great things about doing a TV show is you have a bit of stability for a while. Actors are freelancers. Now I’m plunged back into not knowing where my next job is coming from, and
                                        that’s a terrifying existence.
Couldn’t it also be exhilarating?
Yes, but I’m not a born optimist.
Unlike Zoey?
Very unlike Zoey.
That’s a testament to your acting ability.
I’ll take it.

prompt: “I’m glad that it’s not my responsibility to figure out what happens after the lights go out,” said Ms. Wever, a co-star of the Showtime series.

text:
**Title: Lights Out: Insights from Ms. Wever on The Uncertainty of Life Beyond the Screen**

**By [Your Name]**  
*October 20, 2023*

In an exclusive interview, the multidimensional talent Ms. Wever, renowned for her remarkable portrayal in the Emmy-nominated Showtime series, shared her profound reflections on the complexities of life both on and off the set. Amidst her busy filming schedule, Wever emphasized a sentiment that resonates with many: “I’m glad that it’s not my responsibility to figure out what happens after the lights go out.”

### A Moment of Reflection

Wever's comments came during a candid discussion about the pressures and expectations that accompany an acting career. As an artist, she often grapples with the balance between her on-screen persona and her private life. The notion of "after the lights go out" can be interpreted in various ways — from the literal conclusion of a filming day to the metaphorical uncertainties that life presents.

“It’s a freeing thought,” Wever continued, elaborating on the idea that as a performer, her role is to give life to characters without the burden of deciding their ultimate fates. “We, as actors, present stories, but the audience ultimately engages with those narratives in their own ways. We’re here to ignite discussions, not close chapters.”

### The Weight of Expectations

In an era when the lines between celebrity and reality blur, the expectation for actors to have all the answers—whether about their characters or societal issues—can be daunting. Wever’s perspective serves as a refreshing reminder that vulnerability and uncertainty are part of the human condition, extending beyond the silver screen.

The Showtime series in which Wever stars has touched upon themes of existentialism and moral ambiguity. Audiences have resonated with these narratives, grappling with their own interpretations and conclusions. For Wever, this engagement signifies a success; she hopes her performance inspires viewers to reflect on their realities rather than wait for definitive answers.

### Crafting Characters with Complexity

As Ms. Wever delves deeper into her character’s complexities, she acknowledges the paradox of her profession: “We create these multi-layered individuals who experience conflict and resolution, but often, we don’t provide the neat wrap-up that people crave.” This sentiment echoes in numerous works of drama, where the story doesn’t end with a traditional resolution, leaving characters—and viewers—forever altered.

In her role, Wever poses difficult questions rather than providing clear solutions. This aligns with the current cultural climate, where audiences are increasingly inclined toward narratives that reflect the unpredictability of real life.

### Conclusion: Embracing the Unknown

“I’m glad that it’s not my responsibility to figure out what happens after the lights go out,” is not just a statement about acting but a broader commentary on life itself. As Ms. Wever continues to navigate the intricacies of her craft, she invites her audience to join her in embracing the unknown, illustrating that perhaps the journey, with all its uncertainties, is where true fulfillment lies.

In this unpredictable landscape of storytelling and existence, Ms. Wever stands as a beacon of authenticity, encouraging a dialogue that transcends the screen—one that invites contemplation over resolution, and a deeper understanding of the human experience.

---

*For continuous updates on Ms. Wever's projects and insights into her artistic journey, follow our Arts & Culture section.*

Music and Clowns
What I wish people understood about having a family member with Down syndrome.
Do you know that — Mm. — you’re a complete mystery to me. I don’t know what you’re thinking. Mm, mm. Can you give me a clue? Queen. You were thinking about the queen? Mm. O.K. How do you feel about me — Mm. — making a film about you? [LAUGHS] You just kissed my microphone. [MUSIC PLAYING] Can you help me introduce the characters in the film? So what’s your name? Jamie. And what’s my name? Clown. I’m not a clown. Here’s some family photos. Show me who you can see. Who’s that? Mummy. And who’s that there? Who’s that at the end? That’s Daddy. Daddy. Who’s that? Alex. And next to him? D. “No, no.” [LAUGHTER] Who is it? Jamie. That’s right. Mm, mm. What are you doing? Well, it’s my place, sitting over here. Yep. Ready? Steady? What do you imagine he thinks of you? I don’t think he analyzes things at all as you tend to. When I’m stressed or maybe not even known I was stressed, he’s come up to me and just touched my arm. And you can almost feel it draining away. It feels like a lightning conductor, just a small touch. What do you think he’s trying to do? I don’t think he’s trying to do anything. He’s just empathetic. So he understands how you see things. I think he understands how you feel probably better than you do. What he thinks is a mystery to me. I have no idea what’s going on in his head. Maybe nothing is. It could be a total blank. Mm, mm. Mm. But I’ve no idea. I’ve no idea how — what goes on in his head. I mean, he loves food. Anything to do with cooking and food, he’s there like a shot. Because he enjoys his food. But then he hasn’t got that much else in his life really. Music. Music, yes. Oh yes, he likes music. ABBA [MUSIC PLAYING] Mm. And of course, the circus. He’s mad about clowns — The circus. — and the circus. [HORN PLAYING] Do you know where that came from? No, not at all. I mean, he’d obviously like to be a clown. Maybe that’s — hiding behind the mask. I don’t know. No, no, no. I don’t think he wants to be a clown. I think he likes what they portray, which is a nice and simple mime of life. But he’s got the family sense of humor. [MUSIC INTENSIFIES] I just looked at him. I just knew. And that was good, knowing from the beginning. Because I think it’s harder if you think you’ve got a normal child and then find out later that then there’s something wrong with them. So you could sort of grieve all at the beginning really. So it was. It was like a bereavement. You’re grieving for the child that you hoped you’d have instead of which you’ve got this other child. I remember finding out that he got Down syndrome and just holding him and thinking, oh dear, start again. When did your own feelings settle down? No, no. That was just an instant. Clearly life would not be the same without Jamie. He’s a blessing. Yes, I, I — a bit bemused when people hear they’re having Down’s children and only see the negative side. But there are lots of positive sides. There’s a video of Jamie and Guy playing recorders. And he’s about 6 maybe, and he’s full of energy. And that slowly, slowly diminished. I feel like it correlates with moving out. Yes, it does actually. Because that’s the same time he stopped getting any sort of educational programs, even, like, not being around the rest of the family. Yeah, no, you’re right. It did change him. We worry about the future of how he will cope when we’re dead. So our plan was to find somewhere, which we have. He’s got to get used to the place. And then we’ll disappear, and it won’t be quite so bad. The impact is that carers are paid to do things for him. So he no longer talks or does things for himself because he doesn’t need to. Yeah, no, you’re right. But you never know. You can only do what you think is best at the time. And really, you can’t regret what you do. What’s your plan for Jamie in the future in terms of living? I found an institution, a charity that provides housing and all sorts of things. So I don’t want to put that guilt onto any of my children. But I just hope they would look after him. I know people get busy lives and forget. But I should hate to think of him in his own little world and then none of his siblings taking an interest. We’re all quite spread out now. We are, yeah. But that’s irrelevant. O.K. I feel like I’m being told off. [LAUGHTER] You are, you are. [MUSIC PLAYING]

prompt: What I wish people understood about having a family member with Down syndrome.

text:
**What I Wish People Understood About Having a Family Member with Down Syndrome**

*By [Your Name]*  
*Published: [Date]*

Having a family member with Down syndrome can be one of life's most rewarding experiences, yet it also comes with unique challenges and misconceptions. Through love, patience, and understanding, families navigate a journey that is often underappreciated by society. Here are important insights that I wish people would understand about living with a family member who has Down syndrome.

### 1. **Each Person is Unique**

First and foremost, it's vital to remember that individuals with Down syndrome are just that—individuals. Each person brings their own personality, interests, and talents to the table. Generalizations about capabilities or behaviors can be harmful. Families not only cherish the unique traits of their loved ones but also advocate for their recognition and respect as individuals.

### 2. **The Misconceptions of Limitations**

One of the most prevalent misconceptions is that individuals with Down syndrome have limited potential. Contrary to this belief, many thrive in various environments, including educational, vocational, and social settings. With the right support and resources, they can achieve academic success, hold meaningful jobs, and lead active lives. Advocacy for inclusive programs is crucial.

### 3. **Support Systems Matter**

Families often invest significant time and resources in navigating the systems that support their loved ones. From accessing early intervention services to finding suitable schools and supportive workplaces, the journey can be intricate. Understanding that this process is often overwhelming and complex would help foster empathy and support from the community.

### 4. **The Importance of Inclusion**

Inclusion is not merely a buzzword; it is essential. Whether at school, in community activities, or in social settings, having family members with Down syndrome included fosters a culture of acceptance and understanding. It's crucial for peers and the community to actively engage with individuals with Down syndrome, as it nurtures mutual respect and enriches everyone's experience.

### 5. **The Emotional Toll on Families**

Caring for a family member with Down syndrome can come with emotional highs and lows. Families may experience a rollercoaster of feelings, from joy and pride in their loved one’s achievements to worries about their future. Acknowledging the emotional labor involved allows for a deeper understanding of the challenges families face and the support they might need.

### 6. **Community Support Makes a Difference**

For families navigating the complexities of life with a loved one with Down syndrome, community support can make a profound difference. Organizations that provide resources, workshops, and social events create a network of encouragement. Communities that embrace and empower families strengthen the fabric of society.

### 7. **Celebrating Achievements, Large and Small**

Every milestone matters. Whether it’s a small step in personal development or a significant accomplishment, families take immense pride in every achievement. Celebrating these moments fosters positivity and inspires continued growth, not only for the individual with Down syndrome but for the entire family.

### Conclusion

Having a family member with Down syndrome is not about limitations but rather about possibilities. By fostering understanding, empathy, and inclusion, we can create a more supportive society. It is essential for everyone to recognize the beauty and challenges that come with this unique experience—appreciating it for what it truly is: a journey filled with love, growth, and incredible moments.

*For more insights and stories on individuals with Down syndrome and their families, follow us on our journey through advocacy and awareness.* 

---

*Please share your thoughts and experiences in the comments below.*

text:
# The Maps Behind the Decision: How Michael R. Bloomberg's Aides Analyzed His Impact on the Presidential Race

In the lead-up to the 2020 presidential election, former New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made headlines with his late entry into the Democratic primary. As Bloomberg's team strategized about his potential impact, they relied on a complex and comprehensive series of internal maps. These tools provided a crucial visual representation of not only where he would campaign but also how his candidacy could influence voter demographics and electoral outcomes across the United States.

## The Purpose of the Maps

Bloomberg's aides utilized these maps to glean insights into key battleground states, projecting how his presence in the race would sway votes. By analyzing demographic data, historical voting patterns, and polling results, the maps served multiple purposes:

1. **Identifying Key States**: The maps highlighted critical states for Democratic success, including Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin. These swing states were pivotal in determining the outcome of the election and became focal points for Bloomberg's campaign efforts.

2. **Understanding Voter Demographics**: Each map was layered with detailed demographic information. Bloomberg's advisors assessed voter preferences across various groups—age, ethnicity, income levels, and urban versus rural divides—which allowed the team to tailor their outreach strategies accordingly.

3. **Projecting Electoral Outcomes**: The internal maps also included electoral projections based on hypothetical matchups against key candidates like Joe Biden and Donald Trump. This data allowed Bloomberg's team to strategize not only for the primary but also for a potential general election candidacy.

## Strategic Insights Gained

Through the mapping analyses, Bloomberg’s aides derived several strategic insights that informed their campaign decisions:

- **Cultivating Support in Diverse Communities**: The maps revealed the necessity of engaging different demographic groups. For instance, targeting urban communities and minority voters became a crucial part of Bloomberg's strategy, given their disproportionate influence in Democratic primaries.

- **Impact of Media and Messaging**: With maps illustrating the regions most responsive to advertising and media campaigns, Bloomberg's aides were able to craft specific messages tailored to diverse audiences, emphasizing issues that resonated on both local and national levels.

- **Resource Allocation**: The visual data highlighted where to concentrate campaign resources, from financial investment in advertising to boots-on-the-ground volunteer efforts, maximizing the efficacy of their outreach.

## Challenges Encountered

Despite the utility of these maps, Bloomberg’s team faced significant challenges. The nuances of voter sentiment could not always be captured visually. Disparities in perception and reaction to Bloomberg's wealth and past policies created a complicated landscape that required adaptation beyond what the maps could predict. Moreover, the rise of progressive candidates like Bernie Sanders drew attention away from Bloomberg, affecting his appeal among younger voters.

## Conclusion: A New Model for Campaign Strategy

The internal maps crafted by Michael R. Bloomberg’s aides exemplify an evolving model of political strategy in the digital age. By integrating data visualization with traditional campaign tactics, Bloomberg's team aimed to chart a course through an unpredictable electoral landscape. While his campaign ultimately did not result in the nomination, the methods employed provide a case study in how data-driven strategies might influence future electoral contests, emphasizing the importance of adaptability and nuanced engagement in political campaigning.

As campaigns continue to embrace technology and data analytics, the legacy of Bloomberg’s maps may resonate as a pivotal point in understanding the intricate dance of modern American politics.

*By [Your Name]*  
*October 2023*

In the bustling heart of [City Name], a culinary treasure awaits those who seek a genuine taste of Cuban heritage. **The Journey of Pilar Cuban Bakery**

Founded by [Founder's Name] in [Year Established], Pilar Cuban Bakery began its journey as a small establishment focused primarily on creating traditional Cuban lard bread. This iconic loaf, known for its flaky crust and rich, savory flavor, quickly garnered a devoted following. As the bakery gained popularity, the vision expanded beyond a single offering, leading to an innovative exploration of various filled pastries.

The name "Pilar" pays homage to [Explain the significance of the name, if applicable], further grounding the bakery's identity in the Cuban cultural landscape. Over the years, Pilar Cuban Bakery has grown, yet it continues to maintain its core values of quality, tradition, and community.

**A Menu Rich in Flavor and Tradition**

What sets Pilar Cuban Bakery apart from other eateries is its dedication to crafting delightful filled pastries. From savory empanadas to sweet pastries, the menu is a celebration of both classic and contemporary Cuban flavors. Notable highlights include:

- **Empanadas**: These flaky pastries are stuffed with a variety of fillings, including seasoned ground beef, chicken, and spinach and cheese. Each empanada showcases the skill of the bakers and the vibrant flavors of Cuban cuisine.

- **Pasteles de Guava**: A sweet treat that combines the tartness of guava with a buttery pastry shell, these pastelitos are a must-try for those with a sweet tooth.

- **Cuban Sandwiches**: Though not a pastry, the Cuban sandwich is a staple at Pilar, featuring layers of pork, ham, Swiss cheese, pickles, and mustard pressed between Cuban bread. 

- **Torticas de Morón**: These traditional Cuban cookies, made with coconut and sugar, offer a delightful crunch, perfect for pairing with a cup of café con leche.

**Authenticity and Quality**

At Pilar Cuban Bakery, the commitment to quality is evident in every bite. Ingredients are sourced with care, and recipes are rooted in tradition. The bakery prides itself on using artisanal techniques to create the perfect balance of flavors and textures, ensuring that each pastry tells a story.

The skilled bakers at Pilar have perfected the art of preparation, often seen hand-rolling dough and crafting fillings from scratch. This dedication to craftsmanship is what keeps patrons returning, eager to indulge in their favorite treats or discover new ones.

**Community and Culture**

Regular events celebrating Cuban art, music, and food bring people together, fostering a sense of belonging. The inviting atmosphere and friendly staff create an experience that transcends mere dining; it's a celebration of Cuban culture.

Customers often remark on the bakery's ability to evoke nostalgia, transporting them back to their childhood homes where the aroma of fresh pastries filled the air. This connection to heritage is cherished by locals and visitors alike, making Pilar Cuban Bakery a true cornerstone of the community.

**Conclusion**

Pilar Cuban Bakery has evolved from a simple lard bread shop into a culinary destination that excels in the art of stuffing and filling. text:
# A Smarter Way to Clean Your Home: Innovations to Revolutionize Your Cleaning Routine

## Introduction

Cleaning the home is an essential aspect of maintaining a healthy and pleasant living environment. However, many people find traditional cleaning methods time-consuming and often ineffective. In this age of technology and innovation, a smarter way to clean is emerging, offering efficient solutions that save time, reduce effort, and improve overall cleanliness. This article explores the latest advancements in home cleaning technology, eco-friendly solutions, and smart organization tips to elevate your cleaning routine.

## 1. Embracing Technology

### Robotic Vacuum Cleaners

Among the most significant innovations in home cleaning are robotic vacuum cleaners. Devices such as the Roomba and Roborock go beyond simply vacuuming. They employ advanced mapping technology, allowing them to navigate your home and clean efficiently. Many models can be controlled via smartphone apps, letting you schedule cleanings or activate them while you're away. 

### Smart Cleaning Gadgets

In addition to robotic vacuums, the market is saturated with smart cleaning gadgets that simplify household chores. For instance, automatic window cleaners and self-cleaning mops combine technology and convenience, allowing you to maintain cleanliness with minimal effort. These gadgets are designed to integrate with home automation systems, making it easier to control all your cleaning tasks from a single device.

## 2. Eco-Friendly Cleaning Solutions

### Sustainable Products

As awareness of environmental issues grows, many homeowners are turning to eco-friendly cleaning products. Brands like Seventh Generation and Method produce biodegradable formulations that reduce the chemical footprint left in our homes. These products are not only better for the environment but often safer for your family and pets.

### DIY Cleaning Solutions

Creating your own cleaning products using simple ingredients like vinegar, baking soda, and essential oils is another effective way to ensure a clean home without harsh chemicals. Not only are DIY solutions budget-friendly, but they also allow you to customize fragrances and properties to suit your preferences.

## 3. The Power of Organization

### Decluttering Techniques

A clean home is often a decluttered home. The KonMari method and other minimalist philosophies encourage homeowners to evaluate what items they truly need and cherish. By reducing clutter, you minimize the surface area that requires cleaning, making maintenance easier and more efficient.

### Smart Storage Solutions

Investing in smart storage solutions—such as clear bins, label makers, and multi-functional furniture—can help streamline organization. Keeping items in designated places reduces the time spent locating cleaning supplies and can inspire a more consistent cleaning routine.

## 4. Creating a Cleaning Schedule

A structured cleaning schedule can enhance efficiency and ensure that all areas of your home receive the attention they need. Divide tasks into daily, weekly, and monthly responsibilities. For example:

- **Daily**: Make the bed, wash dishes, and wipe down counters.
- **Weekly**: Vacuum floors, dust surfaces, and clean bathrooms.
- **Monthly**: Clear out the refrigerator, deep clean carpets, and organize closets.

Using digital tools, such as calendar apps or cleaning management systems, can aid in adhering to this schedule.

## Conclusion

Innovations in technology, eco-friendly products, and smart organizational practices are redefining how we approach home cleaning. By adopting these smarter cleaning methods, homeowners can reduce the time and effort spent on housekeeping tasks while maintaining a healthy and inviting environment. As we continue to discover and implement more efficient cleaning solutions, the future of home maintenance looks brighter than ever. Embrace these changes, and enjoy a cleaner home with less hassle. 

---

This approach to cleaning not only enhances efficiency but also propels us towards a more sustainable lifestyle. As we navigate the complexities of modern living, the quest for a smarter cleaning routine brings us one step closer to creating healthier homes for ourselves and future generations.
label: ai
prompt: A Smarter Way to Clean Your Home

text:
**Title: Return to Angola: Portugal's Economic Shift Sparks Reverse Migration to its Former Colony**

**By [Author Name] | Date: October 15, 2023**

**Introduction**

In recent years, Portugal has faced a series of economic challenges that have caused many of its citizens to reconsider their future at home. This economic downturn has fueled a notable and complex migration trend, leading some Portuguese nationals to return to Angola, the country's former colony and a nation rich in natural resources, particularly oil. This article explores the intricacies of this reversed migration pattern, highlighting how historical dynamics have shifted—now placing Europeans in a subservient role in this burgeoning narrative.

**Background: Economic Turmoil in Portugal**

The Portuguese economy has struggled significantly in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, grappling with high inflation, rising unemployment, and stagnant wage growth. The European Central Bank's monetary policies have further complicated recovery efforts, leaving many disillusioned with the prospects of life in Portugal. As opportunities dwindled, a generation of young Portuguese, previously captivated by dreams of stability and prosperity at home, began turning their gaze toward Angola—a land rich with opportunities amid a rapidly changing socio-economic landscape.

**The New Angola: Opportunities Amidst Challenges**

Angola, once considered a tumultuous young nation emerging from decades of civil war, has transformed significantly since gaining independence from Portugal in 1975. With vast reserves of oil and natural resources, Angola has become an attractive destination for investment and employment. The Angolan government, keen on revitalizing its economy and diversifying beyond oil dependence, is making strides to create a more conducive environment for international workers. This new reality is emblematic of Angola's shifting status—an economic landscape that now presents opportunities for returning Portuguese nationals.

**Cultural and Economic Bonds Resurface**

The shared linguistic and cultural ties between Portugal and Angola serve as a crucial bridge for would-be migrants. For many Portuguese, the prospect of working in Angola is more than just an economic decision—it is also a return to familiar cultural landscapes, intertwining familial connections, and shared heritage. In cities like Luanda, Portuguese citizens find themselves reintegrating into societal frameworks where they have familial roots and an understanding of the local culture, but this time as international—not colonial—participants in the economic narrative.

**A Shift in Power Dynamics**

The migration from Portugal to Angola represents a fundamental shift in power dynamics reminiscent of colonial history. Historically, the roles were more straightforward: Portugal, as the colonial power, wielded control and influence over Angola. Today, however, this relationship has evolved dramatically. Angolans are now concerned with correcting historic injustices and asserting their sovereignty, rendering Portuguese nationals less dominant in an economic sense. In this scenario, Europeans are finding themselves in a subservient role, navigating the complexities of a nation once seen primarily as a colony.

**Challenges on the Ground**

Despite the budding opportunities, the return migration to Angola is not without its challenges. Portuguese migrants may encounter cultural differences, bureaucratic hurdles, and the realities of navigating a developing economy with its own diversities and difficulties. Furthermore, the socio-political atmosphere in Angola remains delicate, requiring newcomers to approach their reintegration with sensitivity and respect for local customs and governance.

**Conclusion: A New Era of Migration**

The return of Portuguese citizens to Angola marks a significant transition in the historical narrative between the two nations. As Portugal faces economic challenges and demographic changes, Angola's burgeoning economy presents a unique opportunity for migration. This flow of movement encapsulates not only the resilience of individuals seeking better prospects but also an evolving relationship between two nations learning to navigate their intertwined futures. In this new era, the Europeans, once the colonizers, are now adapting to an African landscape that offers both promise and complexity.

**Call to Action**

As we continue to monitor these dynamic migration trends, it is essential to facilitate understanding and foster dialogue between cultures, ensuring that the future is shaped collaboratively—one that honors both history and the promise of innovation, cooperation, and mutual growth.

---

For further updates and insights into evolving migration patterns and the global economy, follow us @NYTimes on Twitter.
label: ai

prompt: The New York Times traveled with a paramilitary group that says it refuses to leave the front lines in Ukraine’s war in the east. But the government denies that they’re even there. What role can they have in a larger conflict with Russia?

text:
**The Quiet Warriors: An Inside Look at Ukraine’s Paramilitary Frontlines**

*By [Author Name]*  
*Published: [Date]*

As the sun sets over the war-torn landscapes of eastern Ukraine, a shadowy group of fighters remains steadfast at the front lines, asserting a crucial yet contentious role in the ongoing conflict with Russia. The New York Times recently ventured into this precarious territory to uncover the complexities surrounding a paramilitary organization that has taken it upon itself to defend Ukrainian sovereignty against Russian aggression. Despite their palpable presence, Ukrainian government officials deny the legitimacy of these groups, posing an intriguing question: what role do these paramilitaries play in a broader strategy against a resurgent Russia?

### The Paramilitary Landscape

Ukrainian paramilitary groups have emerged in the wake of Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014, evolving from volunteer battalions to organized units engaged in a multifaceted struggle. These groups often fill critical gaps in Ukrainian military capabilities, providing both manpower and specialized skills, as official military resources strain under the conflict’s protracted nature. Many of these fighters are motivated by nationalism, a sense of duty, and personal histories characterized by loss and resistance.

The specific group we accompanied, calling themselves the "Defenders of Freedom," comprises veterans of previous conflicts and civilians alike, trained in guerrilla warfare and urban combat. They claim to have established control over several strategic points in the Donbas region, with a fierce dedication to holding the line against separatist forces backed by Russia. "We will not leave," stated one member, a veteran with scars both visible and invisible. "As long as the threat exists, we will defend our land."

### Denial and Disavowal

Despite their active engagement in combat, the Ukrainian government officially disavows these paramilitary units, citing concerns over control and accountability. Government spokespeople have consistently argued that the existence of these groups complicates the national narrative of a unified front in the war against Russia. “They act independently of any structures we have in place,” a senior military official remarked, hinting at both the risks and potential repercussions of such rogue entities.

This disconnection raises a critical issue—how can Ukraine maintain a coherent military strategy when segments of its front lines are operated by unofficial actors? Amidst the chaos of war, the government faces a delicate balancing act between leveraging these paramilitary efforts and avoiding the pitfalls of fragmentation that could arise from unchecked power dynamics.

### The Impact on the Conflict with Russia

The presence of paramilitary groups like the Defenders of Freedom not only influences the immediate battlefield but also shapes the geopolitical landscape of the region. On one hand, these fighters bolster Ukraine's defenses, demonstrating resilience and patriotism at a time when international support remains crucial yet inconsistent. Their intimate knowledge of local geography and deep-rooted connections to the community lend them an advantage against more conventional Russian forces.

Conversely, the existence of these groups introduces significant risks. Paramilitary units often act outside the purview of formal military discipline, leading to potential human rights violations and complications in diplomatic negotiations. The Russian side has seized upon these narratives, framing the situation as a threat to stability and justifying its military actions under the pretense of protecting ethnic Russians in Ukraine. Such narratives resonate globally, complicating Ukraine's appeal for international solidarity and intervention.

### Looking to the Future

As the conflict drags on and the winter months approach, the question of the future role of paramilitary groups becomes increasingly pressing. With unresolved tensions and the risk of escalation, their influence on both military strategy and domestic stability will be pivotal.

Experts argue that for Ukraine to effectively counter the larger Russian threat, a more integrated approach is necessary—one that seeks to incorporate these fighters into a coordinated framework while retaining governmental oversight and accountability. “There is strength in unity, even among diverse forces,” said a military analyst observing the evolving dynamics. “The challenge is to channel that strength constructively.”

As the frontline heats up and the world watches, the fate of these paramilitary groups, the legitimacy of their actions, and their role in the larger conflict with Russia hang in the balance. With their commitment unwavering, they stand as both an embodiment of Ukraine’s resilience and a symbol of the complexities that define contemporary warfare. 

### Conclusion

The New York Times’ journey alongside the Defenders of Freedom sheds light on a dimension of the Ukrainian conflict often cloaked in controversy and denial. As these warriors navigate the complexities of loyalty, legality, and strategy in their fight for their homeland, the geopolitical implications are vast, leaving international observers questioning how far Ukraine can go without a unified front amid the chaos. 

*For more insights and developments from the front lines of Ukraine, follow our ongoing coverage at The New York Times.*

text:
**Title: A Closer Look at the Hermès Fall 2020 Collection: Timeless Elegance Meets Modernity**

**Introduction**  
The Hermès Fall 2020 Collection, showcased during Paris Fashion Week, captivated audiences with its masterful blend of traditional craftsmanship and contemporary styling. Known for its commitment to quality and innovation, the luxury fashion powerhouse presented a line that exudes sophistication while offering a fresh perspective to the classic house aesthetic.

**1. The Inspiration Behind the Collection**  
Creative Director Véronique Nichanian drew inspiration from the concept of “home” and the comfort it brings in times of uncertainty. This theme resonated throughout the collection, with designs that feature a warm palette and silhouettes reminiscent of cozy interiors, while maintaining the structured elegance Hermès is celebrated for.

**2. Color Palettes and Textiles**  
The collection embraced an earthy color palette, utilizing shades of rust, moss green, and deep navy. Fabrics were selected for their texture and durability, featuring cashmere, wool, and soft leathers. The integration of these materials not only exemplifies Hermès' craftsmanship but also aligns with the growing demand for sustainable fashion.

**3. Key Looks from the Runway**  
Each piece in the Fall 2020 collection tells its own story. Here are some standout looks:

- **The Oversized Coat:** A statement oversized coat in rich caramel wool, cinched at the waist with a leather belt, offered a modern silhouette that caters to both style and comfort.
- **Layered Textures:** The combination of a sleek turtleneck and a voluminous midi skirt highlighted the art of layering. Rich textures met in harmonious balance, showcasing both elegance and practicality.
- **Equestrian Influence:** True to Hermès' heritage, equestrian-inspired elements were woven throughout the collection. This was evident in tailored trousers and riding boots, underscoring the brand’s roots while maintaining a contemporary edge.
- **Accessories that Steal the Show:** The collection featured bold accessories, including oversized bags and statement scarves. Each piece, meticulously crafted, reinforced the notion that accessories can elevate an outfit to new heights.

**4. Footwear: Function Meets Fashion**  
Footwear in the Fall 2020 collection was characterized by practicality and style. Elegant ankle boots with sleek lines and sturdy heels provided versatility, suitable for both casual outings and formal engagements. The use of high-quality leather ensured that each pair was not only a fashion statement but also durable.

**5. Conclusion: A Testament to Timelessness**  
The Hermès Fall 2020 Collection ultimately served as a reminder of the brand's unwavering commitment to excellence. By marrying the coziness of home aesthetics with the sophistication of runway fashion, Hermès created a collection that is both timeless and timely. As the fashion world continues to shift, Hermès stands strong, affirming its place at the pinnacle of luxury fashion.

**Call to Action: Experience the Collection**  
For those eager to explore this season’s offerings, the Hermès Fall 2020 Collection is now available online and in select stores. Embrace the elegance and craftsmanship of Hermès, and discover pieces that combine beauty with enduring quality.

---

This article offers a deep dive into the Hermès Fall 2020 Collection, presenting insights that would engage readers looking for a comprehensive overview of the luxury brand's latest runway offerings.

Magazine|Royal Robbins and the Fight for the Soul of Rock Climbing
Site Search Navigation
Site Navigation

Royal Robbins and the Fight for the Soul of Rock Climbing
ByDANIEL DUANEDEC. 28, 2017
He erased his rival in a battle for the soul of climbing.
The New York Times
The Lives They Lived
The Lives They Lived
Remembering some of the artists, innovators and thinkers we lost in the past year. For readers’ tributes to loved ones who died this year, seeThe Lives They Loved.
B. 1935
B. 1935
Royal Robbins
He erased his rival in a battle for the soul of climbing.
One cold mountain night in 1971, Royal Shannon Robbins dangled from ropes hundreds of feet up the gigantic Yosemite cliff called El Capitan, clutching a hammer and chisel and worrying that he had made a shameful mistake. The most influential American rock climber of the 20th century, and a serious-minded fellow who disdained vanity, Robbins had spent that whole day chopping steel bolts off El Capitan, obliterating the climbing route called Wall of the Early Morning Light, created by his alcoholic rival, Warren Harding.
Robbins saw climbing as spiritually exalted — “a game in which we play at acquiring the courage necessary to a beautiful life,” as he once put it. The sport, in his view, should always be a quest for self-understanding, not self-aggrandizement. Climbers who made first ascents should consider themselves artists creating aesthetic pathways for others to follow. The canvas of the great rock walls was finite — there was only so much cliff — so those who claimed a piece of it had a responsibility to climb along natural rock features and minimize the use of permanent safety hardware, like bolts. To ignore that responsibility was to sin against the larger climbing community.
Harding found all this pompous and ridiculous. A California road surveyor who loved fast cars, he saw climbing as an enjoyable but silly vice and felt no responsibility to anybody. To establish Wall of the Early Morning Light, a 3,000-foot sweep of golden granite, Harding and his partner lived out of hammocks for 27 days and drank cheap wine while pandering to the TV news crews filming them. Worst of all, in Robbins’s view, Harding ascended huge blank sections of rock by drilling more than 300 bolts and then clipping on stirrups to eliminate difficulty and risk.
Robbins craved order, greatness and the confidence that he was doing the right thing. Born in West Virginia in 1935, he suffered early abandonment by his father, also named Royal (“Ah, Dad, why did you leave me?” he wrote in an autobiography titled “To Be Brave”). Then came years of abuse by an alcoholic stepfather named James Chandler, who moved the family to California and changed Robbins’s name to his own. Robbins was 10 when he heard his mother beg his stepfather to put down a knife. Robbins ran for help, Chandler disappeared and Robbins soon reclaimed his birth name and resolved to become a better man than either of his fathers.
He found schoolwork difficult but climbing easy. He first climbed in Yosemite in 1952 at the dawn of the sport’s true golden age, when equipment and techniques were finally mature enough for the biggest walls, but Yosemite’s marquee cliffs remained unclimbed. The obvious first plum was the 2,500-foot northwest face of Half Dome, and when Robbins heard that Harding was planning an attempt, Robbins scrambled a team and, in 1957, got to the top first. Harding retaliated by claiming the first ascent of El Capitan. In 45 days’ work spread over 18 months, Harding created the so-called Nose Route by keeping ropes always fixed from his high point to the ground, commuting up and down with food and wine, drilling countless bolts and basking in national publicity.
Robbins was so disturbed that in 1960 he made the second ascent of the Nose Route in just seven days. A year later, Robbins demonstrated just how retrograde Harding’s methods were by doing his own first ascent of a different route on El Capitan in just 12 days and with very few bolts. The resulting route, called the Salathé Wall, is still perhaps the greatest long rock climb on Earth.
Robbins and Harding kept up their amiable competition — for prestigious first ascents and the soul of the sport — throughout the 1960s. Each time Harding or anyone else established a big new route, Robbins repeated it in better style: faster, sometimes alone, occasionally chopping bolts he deemed unnecessary. When not climbing, Robbins played tennis, read Ralph Waldo Emerson and wrote essays calling at least one of his own climbs “better even than Mozart.” Harding wasn’t the only one who thought Robbins ought to lighten up, but many leading climbers shared Robbins’s belief that first ascents should be done in the most adventurous way possible, with minimal damage to the wall.
So when Harding spent nearly a month drilling his way up Wall of the Early Morning Light in 1970, with constant network-news coverage, Robbins was on firm social footing in declaring the route “contrived and artificial.” A year later, with a partner named Don Lauria, Robbins started up Harding’s opus with hammer and chisel, beginning an operation without precedent in the history of the sport — the deliberate, violent erasure of a major new climb created by an internationally famous climber.
Early on the first day, however, Robbins encountered an unbolted section of surprising technical delicacy. More bolts followed, and Robbins chopped them, but then he found still more dangerous and challenging stretches, until it became apparent that Harding had taken greater risks and done the route in a more adventurous style than Robbins had imagined. That night, Robbins hung in a bivouac hammock convulsed with self-doubt. He had convinced himself he had the moral authority to obliterate Wall of the Early Morning Light, but a voice inside told Robbins that envy was blinding his better judgment. The next morning, Robbins put away hammer and chisel and, without doing further harm, followed Harding’s route to the summit.
Daniel Duane is the author of the climbing memoir “Lighting Out: A Golden Year in Yosemite and the West.” He last wrote afeaturefor the magazine about the climber Alex Honnold.
B. 1936
B. 1936
Mary Tyler Moore
She defined the idea of women in the workplace — while constantly in search of herself.
There was a scene that Robert Redford wanted for “Ordinary People” in which Beth Jarrett, played by Mary Tyler Moore, takes a cake out of the refrigerator. The cake has a circle of cherries on top, and the only action in the scene is Beth, the cold, bereaved mother, looking at the cake, adjusting the cherries, then putting the cake back in the fridge. Moore was alone in the kitchen. Redford wanted to capture Beth in an unobserved moment — what was this woman really like? How was she coping with the accidental death of her older son and the recent suicide attempt of her younger son? Had she escaped into her fastidiousness and her uptightness?
He shot it once; no good. He shot it again; no good. She tried to bring a motivation to each take: Was this cake good enough? Or, Did the cake need more cherries? And each time he’d say: “No, no, clear your mind. Let’s go again.” Every time the kitchen was set up for another scene, Redford used the opportunity to try the shot again. Moore called it “the bane of the production.” He shot it over and over, 26 times in total in front of a “mystified” crew, she wrote in her memoir.

“The last time he performed with that guitar was at Keith Richards’ place in Jamaica, where they were practicing for the movie “Hail! Hail! Rock ’n’ Roll.” It’s the guitar on which he wrote “Johnny B. Goode,” which ended up on the Voyager. There are these space probes out there with gold-plated, copper records of “Johnny B. Goode.” He loved smaller audiences. He performed 209 times at my restaurant. Sometimes he would nudge the keyboard player aside and play piano. When he was really feeling it, he would sling his long leg up and then let it hit the ground, and the band would know to stop, and he would start reciting poetry or tell a joke. He intuitively choreographed the greatest stage moves — playing the guitar behind his back! He made the guitar a star.”Joe Edwards, owner of Blueberry Hill

Dick Gregory
He chose standing up for black people over stand-up.
If you scan the thousands of pages of Richard Claxton Gregory’s F.B.I. file the way he scanned newspapers and magazines, mining information for material for his comedy, you will find yourself constantly landing on “racial matter” — a phrase preferred by the agency. The file tracks the rare trajectory of a man who made an enormously successful show-business career a footnote to his activism.
Gregory didn’t want people’s fear to stop them from standing up. Page 264 of the first of eight installments of his government file includes a warning from someone who was clearly afraid of this empowerment — so much so that he sent his concerns directly to J. Edgar Hoover by telegram: “I ADVOCATE AND ENCOURAGE ALL FBI AGENTS TO GO AFTER DICK GREGORY IN FULL FORCE. LET NOT ANYONE STOP YOU.”

B. 1933
B. 1933
Jane Juska
She transcended a strict upbringing and embraced her eroticism in her 60s.
You are a 66-year-old mother and retired high-school English teacher, bred in a small, puritanical Ohio town. Though you’ve been divorced for 30 years and celibate for almost that long, your life is full in many ways, teaching a college education course, volunteering as a writing instructor at San Quentin State Prison, escorting women for abortions at Planned Parenthood.
None of it compensates for the lack of a man’s touch. The conventional avenues for dating at your age — senior hikes, senior bird-watching, senior mixers (you even hang out in hardware stores) — have netted little. Online dating is not yet commonplace. So, one October day in 1999, you write 30 words that will appear as a personal ad in The New York Review of Books. “Before I turn 67 — next March — I would like to have a lot of sex with a man I like. If you want to talk first, Trollope works for me.”

B. 1943
Sam Shepard
A selection of beloved objects from those we lost.
“He was always a pinch-front kind of guy, the style is kind of a triangular crease in the front. It’s a strong reminder of the man — of him being outside and on location and involved in the day. There is a practicality and a confidence to it. It’s a well-worn hat. His work was key to his day and it was always about process and project. I was a wrangler on Silent Tongue; it was my first job. I briefly doubled my dad on Don’t Come Knocking because the production wouldn’t let him run a horse hard because he might get hurt as the star. It was the last location work I did with him.”Jesse Shepard, son

B. 1946
B. 1946
Scharlette Holdman
Trying to find out how murderers were made, in order to save their lives.
She lived in a tiny New Orleans cottage filled with Cajun barbecue, Palestinian tapestries, books on torture, dirty jokes and stacks of academic papers on topics like the effects of neurotoxins in fertilizers. For a while there was a deceased inmate in a pine box in her yard, because she believed he deserved a respectful burial, and when no one in his family offered to provide one, she took him home. Ted Kaczynski, the Unabomber, whom she defended against the death penalty, tried to give her his cabin, but the government wouldn’t let her keep it. Sister Helen Prejean liked to come over and play a card game called Beat Your Ass. “Well, hey, come in, come in, come in,” Scharlette Holdman said to everyone who walked onto her screened porch. Her Tennessee drawl, pale skin and wispy blond hair were hard to square with her radical, irreverent, voracious mind. She once fell in love with a man who knocked on her door impersonating the hunchback Igor.
Holdman developed the field of death-penalty mitigation, a dry, abstract term for the floridly fascinating practice of humanizing defendants enough to keep the state from killing them. Her clients — Jared Loughner, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev and Eric Rudolph among them — were hard to love, yet she loved them anyway, and not for sappy or religious reasons. Holdman believed monsters, as the state painted her defendants to be, were made, not born. One question animated her life:What happened to turn you into a person capable of doing this?She understood that if you dug deeply enough into a person’s history, two or three generations if necessary, you would find the original wound, and if you understood the wound and traced its downstream effects, you would care enough to preserve a person’s life.
Read more ▾
B. 1928
B. 1928
Adam West
A superhero for his life and times.
He was 37, and had been a Hollywood B-lister for almost a decade. Every now and then he landed a choice small part — there was that movie with Paul Newman — but his career was mostly a succession of failed TV pilots (eventually 13 in all) and roles in which he was, as he would later write, “shot up, beat up or put on trial.” Just when it looked as if the big break would never come, he was offered a part that might finally make him a household name, help him forget that he was once billed below a chimp. But there was a catch — the character was a comic-book figure already adored, or at least known, by legions. There would beexpectations. And even if he got it right, he risked being typecast for the rest of his career, like most every other actor who ever played a superhero.
This was the dilemma facing Adam West, the former William West Anderson, as he contemplated becoming TV’s Batman in the fall of 1965. He certainly looked and sounded the part: He was tall, handsome, fit, his voice a Bond-like mix of suave and smarm. He had read the comics himself as a boy growing up on a ranch in the Pacific Northwest. But this Batman was different — not the tortured, noirish character who came to life in 1939, in the shadow of totalitarianism, but rather one who was ready for the colorful, splashy 1960s, the brooding cello replaced by a snappy Motown bass. Batman and his heartthrobby teenage sidekick, Robin, would still be saving Gotham City from archcriminals on a weekly basis. But they’d be doing it with a wink and a nudge, hurling pies as often as punches. Five minutes into reading the initial script, West was giggling. He knew it would be a stretch. But if nothing else, he figured, he could have some fun with the part. He took it.
Read more ▾

Prodigy

“After leaving lunch in the city, he decided to make a stop in a small boutique called Shop Untitled, where he tried on a few leather jackets. P. chose this one because of the fit and soft feel. Later, he reached out to his designer friend Gucci Ghost to freestyle customize the jacket. The last two big events he’d worn the jacket to were Q. and A.s on his latest book at Harvard and Yale. B. 1977
B. 1977
Maryam Mirzakhani
She drew her way to mathematical greatness.
Maryam Mirzakhani was a mathematician, but she worked like an artist, always drawing. She liked to crouch on the floor with large sheets of paper, filling them with doodles: repeated floral figures and bulbous, rubbery bodies, their appendages sliced clean away, like denizens of a lost Miyazaki anime. One of her Stanford University graduate students said Mirzakhani portrayed problems in mathematics not as daunting logical conundrums but as animated tableaus. “It’s almost like she had a window on the math landscape, and she was trying to describe how the things living there interacted with each other,” says Jenya Sapir, now an assistant professor at Binghamton University. “To her, it’s all happening at once.”
Mirzakhani grew up in Tehran with dreams of becoming a writer. In sixth grade, she started at Farzanegan, a school for the city’s most gifted girls, and earned the top marks in all of her classes — except math. Near the school year’s end, the instructor returned a math test marked 16 out of 20, and Mirzakhani ripped it up and stuffed the pieces in her bag. She told a friend that she’d had it when it came to math: “I’m not even going to try to do better.” Mirzakhani, though, was constitutionally incapable of not trying, and she soon fell in love with the subject’s spare poetry. As a high school junior, she and her best friend, Roya Beheshti, became the first Iranian women to qualify for the International Mathematical Olympiad, and the next year, in 1995, Mirzakhani took a gold medal with a perfect score.

“He gave it to her when I was born. Anything that Bill gave her was special. He was my godfather, but also my paternal figure. She had a very special way about her that people would find easy to talk to. Occasionally, she would take me to some interviews. When I graduated from high school, we went to Paris, and she did an interview with Truffaut. There’s probably about three seconds of us in ‘Love on the Run.’”Erik Ross, son

B. 1945

Barkley Hendricks
He rejected the label of black political painter.
For 38 years, Barkley Hendricks began his Art 111/112 class by asking each student to bring in three small objects that meant something to them. The items varied, but he dubbed this the bottle-shoe-and-plate project, because these were the objects most students chose. Over the semester, the students would draw and redraw them — in different styles, in different media, in different orders — until he was satisfied. While each student worked, he circled the room, clutching his thermos of tea with honey and lemon, peering at their papers. He was known to harangue students for not-perfectly-rounded teacups or loudly harrumph at overdramatically shadowed plates. “You’re in college,” he would chide those who disappointed him. It was a class people cried in.
At Connecticut College, a small liberal-arts school that had enough blond heads and Vineyard Vines belts around its arboretum that it looked, on certain days, not unlike a country club, Hendricks was considered “intense.” (I should know. I was there.) He made a striking reputation for himself: Students either loved him or hated him. Either way, they warned one another about him: “Knows what he’s doing but kinda mean about it,” read one review on RateMyProfessors.com, a virtual bible of student-generated reviews that was popular on campus. Another wrote, “Consider taking his courses during 2nd semester because he hates winter, so he’s more sympathetic when grades close in the spring!”
Read more ▾
B. 1954
B. 1954
Irina Ratushinskaya
How to be free in the gulag.
At the end of a school day when Irina Ratushinskaya was a fifth grader in the 1960s in Odessa, her teacher stepped out of class and an exuberant student seized the moment to throw a chestnut across the room. The chestnut landed in an inkwell and broke it, splattering ink. Seeing the damage, most of the children hastily packed up and left, but Ratushinskaya and another student, a boy named Seryozha, were in charge of cleaning the classroom after school that day and had to stay. A teacher came in, discovered the broken inkwell and asked them who had done it. Ratushinskaya lied and hedged: “I don’t know, I didn’t see anything, when it happened I was searching for something in my satchel.” But when it was his turn, Seryozha simply said, “I’m not going to tell you.” His answer was a revelation. “It hadn’t even entered my head to say that,” she writes in the second of her two memoirs of Soviet dissent, “In the Beginning” (1991). “How ashamed I felt! How much more to my liking was his answer than mine!”
A poet who became an anti-Soviet activist in her 20s, Ratushinskaya was among the last wave of dissidents whose efforts helped to bring down the Soviet Union. In her years of being harassed, arrested, tried, imprisoned and tortured by the Soviets, she would get far on versions ofI’m not going to tell you.

There’s 50 years of phone contacts in the address book, and there are very eccentric notes throughout about how she met these people.
