Enrico L. Quarantelli
He proved that disasters bring out the best in us.
He was small, bald, smiley, unthreatening; he liked to find a corner, blend in, take notes. It always amazed him: everything you could see, just by looking — also, everything the people he was watching didn’t see. “Last observation to make,” he put in his notes in April 1964, watching the authorities in Anchorage scramble after a colossal earthquake. “It was only on Wednesday that people around the office began to inquire who we were.” He’d been sitting in that office since Sunday.
Enrico Quarantelli was always looking; the compulsion to notice everything, and passively accept nothing, defined him as a sociologist and a human being. “I was born Nov. 10, 1924, in New York City,” he says at the start of an oral-history interview, and when he adds, “For some reason, I remember absolutely nothing of the first five years of my life,” he seems genuinely aggrieved by this lapse in his observational record. The animating moment of his early career came in 1952, after a suite of deadly tornadoes tore through Arkansas. Quarantelli was part of a team from the University of Chicago sent to study the aftermath. The conventional wisdom held that survivors would be petrified and helpless but also, somehow, marauding and clobbering one another for food. (“The premise was that people were sheep, except when they were wolves,” as Rebecca Solnit put it in her book about the myths of disaster response.) But after conducting almost 350 interviews in Arkansas, Quarantelli and his colleagues discovered that virtually everyone acted rationally, even generously. They protected one another. They rushed to look for survivors. There was no traffic jam to frantically flee the disaster area; the traffic coming in, to help, was worse. Quarantelli looked around and realized, he recalled, “This is a different world than what had been assumed.”
Read more ▾
B. 1985
B. 1985
DeMarlon Thomas
Even a president’s clemency couldn’t save him.
DeMarlon Thomas was a native son of Saginaw, a struggling Michigan city hit hard when General Motors plants closed. As he came of age, employment tumbled and crime soared, and Saginaw became the sort of place where it was way too easy to fall into trouble.
As a kid, Thomas mostly dodged Saginaw’s perils, because he was busy playing football in middle school and high school. His mother, Ceaya LaFrance Thomas, gave birth to him when she herself was in high school, so he was raised by his grandmother Willie Jane Thomas while Ceaya finished up. Though Ceaya returned to Saginaw after college and was in Thomas’s life, home for him was at Grandma’s. His mother recalls the bond those two had: “After football practice, he’d go home, take a shower and get in bed with my mama, and they’d curl up and talk about their day. He’d make her laugh. He made everybody laugh.” If Ceaya wanted to spend more time with her son, Willie Jane would say, “Well, you can just spend the night with us” — and she often did.
Read more ▾
B. 1936
B. 1936
Trisha Brown
A selection of beloved objects from those we lost.
“I asked her once what she looks for in a dancer, and she said, ‘Look to the base, look at their ankles.’ She was a ground up kind of dancer. She would use those balls every morning to warm up. She had this system of rolling her body on those balls — shoulders, knees, hips, back. Sometimes I’d be leaving for school and she’d be floating on top of those balls. I always thought she could levitate. It grounded her, and it made her feel like who she was and what she was about.”Adam Martell Brown, son
See more things they loved
B. 1947
B. 1947
Shirley Childress Johnson
She learned from an early age how to convey music without sound.
Shirley Childress Johnson became a professional sign-language interpreter at a time when the number of black sign-language interpreters was vanishingly small. The work was personal: Johnson’s parents were deaf; she learned English and American Sign Language simultaneously. She was profoundly aware of the joys of deaf culture, which demands full face-to-face engagement, as well as the urgency of making basic information accessible to the community. She attended births, trials and presidential inaugurations. She interpreted for Maya Angelou and pro bono for people she met on the street. She wrote that she took in other people’s pain deeply when she translated and struggled to “ventilate her feelings.”
She viewed that emotional sensitivity as a liability in her work, until one day it turned out to be an asset. In 1980, she was invited to work with Sweet Honey in the Rock, the internationally acclaimed African-American women’s a cappella ensemble, who perform lush, intricate arrangements of protest songs, wordless chants, spirituals and poems. The group was started in 1973 by Bernice Johnson Reagon, a preacher’s daughter and a founding member of the S.N.C.C. Freedom Singers, which traveled around the country sharing news about the civil rights movement. The church where Reagon grew up in Albany, Ga., did not have a piano, so she learned her earliest lessons about what music is for and where its power lies by singing unaccompanied; eliminating instruments and paring sound down to just the voice allowed it to unfurl its full range and to join with others more completely.
Read more ▾
B. 1923
B. 1923
John Sarno
At war with the medical establishment — and his own body.
In an elegant uptown apartment, an unhappy doctor with bushy eyebrows and a formal bearing went to sleep each night feeling like a pretender. In the morning, he knew, another batch of wincing patients desperate for relief would be waiting to see him. And he knew, despite his training and his Ivy League degree, that he had nothing meaningful to offer.
John Sarno was a rehabilitation-medicine specialist at N.Y.U., and he was doing what he had been taught — diagnosing pinched nerves and slipped disks, recommending hot pads and bed rest. But as the months passed, the advice he gave his patients left him feeling increasingly bitter. They were in pain, and he was lost.
Read more ▾
B. 1928
B. 1928
Jimmy Breslin
A selection of beloved objects from those we lost.
“He always preferred to be comfortable; the writing was so natural to him, and so was being in pajamas. He didn’t make things complicated. He tried to listen to whatever conversation he could hear. Any time he heard a siren, he wanted to go. He never drove in his life; I used to drive him a lot. If we went someplace, he’d dictate his column over the phone. I’d be driving back on a highway, and we’d look for a telephone booth, and he’d call and say, ‘Gimme the desk.’ ”Ronnie Eldridge, wife
John Pilson is a photographer and filmmaker who is currently working on a video project titled “Parole Parole Parole.”
See more things they loved
B. 1944
B. 1944
S. Allen Counter
He walked in the footsteps of a black explorer who was forgotten by time.
By the time S. Allen Counter got to Greenland in 1986, he had already lived many other lives — Harvard neurophysiologist, explorer, ethnographer, social-justice advocate. But in the howling hinterland, he was just a man possessed by a ghost so powerful that he had followed it into an icy hell. And Counter couldn’t believe his good fortune: to have the privilege of freezing in an igloo among the Inuit, eating walrus heart andkiviaq, little winged auks fermented in sealskin. He was giddy, set down in all of this blank space, searching out justice for a dead black man whose story had been lost under a snowdrift of white history.
Counter, a friend once wrote, was “the most interesting man in the world.” Born in Americus, Ga., he grew up in Boynton Beach and West Palm Beach, Fla., a community full of fruit-pickers and maids and servants, there to support the resort town and the wealthy whites living in seaside mansions like Mar-a-Lago. Jim Crow was a fact of life — segregated schools, beaches, train-station waiting rooms — but by at least one law, West Palm could have been considered progressive: African-Americans were allowed to own their own businesses, as long as they were in the part of town that catered to African-Americans.
Read more ▾
B. 1969
B. 1969
Delia Graff Fara
She philosophized about vagueness — and lived with it too.
The “paradox of the heap” seems at first like a trick, a brainteaser that must have some clever catch. But it reveals itself, as it defies easy understanding, to be a philosophical problem. You might approach it as a puzzle, only to end up devising a solution so deep that it would challenge our thinking about language, knowledge and the nature of reality. By the time of her death from brain cancer in July at 48, Delia Graff Fara, a philosopher at Princeton, had done just that.
Start with a heap of sand. If you remove a single grain, it remains a heap. Repeat this process enough times, however, and you have a heap of sand that contains, say, one grain. This is absurd: One grain is not a heap. Something has gone wrong, but it is not obvious what. Either there is a precise number of grains at which point a heap becomes a nonheap, or there is no such thing as a heap, or classical logic is flawed (perhaps it is only ever sort of true that something is a heap). Which bullet to bite?
Read more ▾
B. 1927
B. 1927
Herbert R. Axelrod
A hustler who built a fortune on a fish tale.
“The most profound change in my life,” Herbert R. Axelrod once recalled, began in 1955, when Axelrod, a New Jersey-based aquarium-fish dealer and the publisher of Tropical Fish Hobbyist magazine, took a steamboat up the Rio Negro, deep in the Brazilian Amazon. He was searching for a supply of wild discus fishes that would allow him to break a rival dealer’s monopoly. Fishless and out of food, he got off at a small town, where he met a German priest, who happened to be a fish hobbyist.
“Yes, there are discus fishes near here,” the priest said. “But we also have neon tetras!” The priest guided Axelrod to a nearby creek and, lifting his cassock, led him into the water, where red-and-blue tetras schooled around their legs. Axelrod returned to New Jersey with “the largest neons I had ever seen” — and sent some to the curator of fishes at the Smithsonian. The curator, the story goes, excitedly called him a few days later: The neons weren’t neons at all. They were an exotic and beautiful new species.
Read more ▾
B. 1926
B. 1926
Harry Dean Stanton
A selection of beloved objects from those we lost.
“He would wake up in the morning and work on the crossword puzzle and the jumble from The L.A. Times. Ed Begley Jr. would call him and say, ‘Hey, did you get 21 across?’ In between, he would watch game shows, like ‘The Chase.’ He always did his crossword in pen, and he could almost memorize the puzzle before writing it down. His passions in life were music and the crossword puzzle. He never cared that much about movies. He just didn’t feel like it was that important.”Sara Stanton, great-niece
John Pilson is a photographer and filmmaker who is currently working on a video project titled “Parole Parole Parole.”
See more things they loved
B. 1960
B. 1960
Erin Moran
A sheltered daughter on TV, she had to fend for herself when the cameras were off.
Young children are not an obvious audience for nostalgia, but those of us who grew up in the 1970s watching “Happy Days” consumed it regularly. We were exposed, week after week, to an idealized version of the ’50s, developing a peculiar longing for a time we never knew.
In real life, the grown-ups around us were acting up: Our parents protested or maybe just divorced, and our mothers went off to work and our babysitters got high or found other ways to rebel. But every Tuesday at 8, there were Marion Cunningham, cheery and aproned, and her hard-working provider, Howard Cunningham, reliably dispensing kindly advice to their well-adjusted children. As characters on other prime-time shows wrestled with racism and sexism, the Cunninghams were, for the most part, still oblivious to the revolutions to come, their comforts unchallenged.
Read more ▾
B. 1951
B. 1951
Maggie Roche
The songs she sang with her sisters were full of joy and harmony — the exact things she struggled to wring out of life.
For their devoted fan base, the Roches’ otherworldly harmonies were like an idealized sound of family. These three sisters’ voices could fly in tight formation across vast long notes and wild melodic curlicues. They could break into plaintive individual solos. The Roches were a quintessential band apart, united in a shared language.
But when the eldest sister, Maggie Roche, received a diagnosis of breast cancer nearly a decade ago, she kept it from her siblings until only months before her death in January. Her fastidious privacy underscores just how much headstrong independence was poured into the Roches’ breezy, blended sound. Maggie’s songs were vignettes of emotional hypersensitivity, and she wrote from experience.
Read more ▾
B. 1927
B. 1927
John Ashbery
A selection of beloved objects from those we lost.
“He has been collecting collage material since he was in college. In a sense, it’s how he writes a poem: using fragments of conversation or something he heard on TV, juxtaposing things and creating environments. Collage is central to his process. It was very much trial and error. You can’t really describe what his collages are specifically about, but they deal with the process and language itself. He was, perhaps, communicating the feeling of creativity.”David Kermani, husband
John Pilson is a photographer and filmmaker who is currently working on a video project titled “Parole Parole Parole.”
See more things they loved
B. 1987
B. 1987
Ren Hang
His photographs scandalized his country.
Jun Sui didn’t plan to get naked for the Chinese art photographer Ren Hang. But as the day wore on, she loosened up, and the clothes came off. Ren’s shoots could become electrified with the illicitness of being nude, especially when they were in public, where such activity in China guarantees arrest or worse. The atmosphere of adventure created trust, as did the spirit of rebellion. “There was a sense of being free,” Sui told me. In person, Sui is demure, inconspicuous; in Ren’s photographs, her eyes blaze from her crouch between two upright women, her arms snaking between their thighs. “We hide the body in our culture,” Ren once said; in China, it is “a demoralization to show what they think should be private.” Ren, Sui said, encouraged everyone around him to shed that conditioning.
Ren once described his work as “satisfying a thirst.” He found beauty in almost everything — a person, a snake, a flower — and trained his camera on his friends and his boyfriend, Jiaqi, turning their bodies into sculptures. In a 2013 Vice interview, the reporter fixated on a series of photographs of people urinating — into the air, on each other, into a colorful tropical drink. “What’s with all the pee in your photos?” the reporter asked, perhaps hoping for a lurid answer. Ren had none. “I like to portray every organ in a fresh, vivid and emotional way,” he said. In other words, urinating isn’t scandalous or erotic — it’s a biological reality, at once amusing and a fact.
Read more ▾
B. 1930
B. 1930
Cheo
The mainland disappointed him. Puerto Rico was his home.
Eighteen hours before Hurricane Maria hit Puerto Rico, Margaret Heredia stood in her kitchen, clutching the phone and looking out over San Francisco Bay. On the other end of the line, thousands of miles away, her aunt Luisa was organizing food and water reserves. She was waiting for an ambulance to pick up Heredia’s father, Cheo, and take him to a facility run by the Department of Veterans Affairs, where he was supposed to stay during the storm.
In their cliff-side homes, Heredia’s family members were hard to reach even in good weather. Sabana Grande Alta, their village, translates roughly to “big blanket in the hills,” a reference to vegetation that grows thicker as you move up into the mountains until it envelopes everything in sight. Bright green leaves seem to grow from everywhere and nowhere; they creep onto the stucco walls and tin roofs of the tiny homes, blending them into their surroundings. Bushes, fruit trees and wildflowers grow back so quickly that people traveling by foot do so with a machete to cut a path to their destination. Thejíbaros, or hill people of Puerto Rico, are known for their ingenuity: They ride bareback on horses and raise chickens and rabbits in their backyards, cooking them into rich stews in their outdoor kitchens.
Read more ▾
B. 1930
B. 1930
Derek Walcott
When the poet claimed his place on the world stage, he took a tiny island with him.
Derek Walcott’s poetry pulsated with every element literature has ever alchemized: nature, the human interior, hardship, joy, tragedy, comedy, the life of the world and the divinity of epic. And it was largely set among everyday people in a place that was often viewed as a backwater of history — a derelict Caribbean outpost of England’s fallen empire, fit for nothing but a future tourist resort.
In 1930, when Walcott and his twin brother, Roderick, were born, the island of St. Lucia was a British colony with a scant population of around 57,000. The twins were raised, along with an elder sister, by their mother, Alix, a schoolteacher. It was a time of rudimentary medicine on the island. Their father, Warwick, died of an ear infection when his sons were a year old. He had been an amateur artist, and Walcott, who knew his father largely from his belongings still in the house, painted from an early age.
Read more ▾
B. 1944
B. 1944
Jonathan Demme
A selection of beloved objects from those we lost.
“I wasn’t an observant bird person until I met Jonathan — he got into bird watching as a child on Long Island. He would do migratory counts; he was a bird nerd from way back. We birded in Central Park. The day that Jonathan died, a friend told me she saw the great horned owl. About a year before, Jonathan and I had visited that owl. So my three kids, my son-in-law and I went on an owl hunt and found it. It felt incredibly meaningful. His Peterson guide was a treasured book. There was always one within reach.”Joanne Howard, wife
John Pilson is a photographer and filmmaker who is currently working on a video project titled “Parole Parole Parole.”
See more things they loved
B. 1936
B. 1936
Glen Campbell
His essential loneliness transcended the rhinestone image.
Certain American artists, over long careers, get so locked into a given persona that it becomes hard, at their deaths, to recall what once excited people about them. Like Bob Hope before him, Glen Campbell was a victim of a kind of hardening of affect. Even with a public diagnosis of Alzheimer’s trailing him, the genial, middle-of-the-road version of “Glen Campbell” became such a durable commodity that I had to work to remind myself what it felt like to first encounter him. That is, to sit in a college dorm in New York City in 1968, listening to “Wichita Lineman” and feeling as if the voice I heard was laying out a kind of alternative narrative for my own time. In a musical landscape dominated by the Doors, Cream and the Beatles, here was a young Southern boy singing — with unaffected honesty — about something those other groups weren’t paying much attention to: the conflict between work and love. To recall this is to marvel all over again at the wild openness of the musical choices available in the late ’60s. There was no embarrassment in choosing to play “Wichita Lineman” alongside the White Album. Jimmy Webb’s lyrics — “And I need you more than want you/And I want you for all time” — were never exactly cool, but they didn’t need to be. To young men trying to figure out how the emotional landscape of early adulthood was likely to feel, they were a kind of signpost. And the singer interpreting them seemed to have risen directly out of the forlorn places he sang about: Wichita, Galveston, Phoenix. Glen Campbell came across as strangely pure.
But purity, when it arrives in an apple-cheeked, all-American form, often bends, unless fiercely protected, to a commercial pressure to become something else. In 1969, Campbell began hosting a TV series, “The Glen Campbell Goodtime Hour.” Though there was nothing “good time” about the Campbell we were introduced to (his early songs, from “Gentle on My Mind” onward, dealt with one form of sorrow or another) and though Campbell worked, over network objections, to find guest spots for underexposed country singers like Waylon Jennings and Merle Haggard, he seemed to get caught up in what was to become a huge wave. In the late-Vietnam, early-Watergate years, the nation needed a little cheering up, and it fell to a newly revised version of “the South” to provide that. The region, unflatteringly represented since the 1940s by film adaptations of Erskine Caldwell, Tennessee Williams and William Faulkner, got a 1970s makeover. The vision of “Tobacco Road” gave way to the vision of “Hee Haw,” the popular TV series whose corn-pone charm prepared the ground for the advent of the good old boy. Burt Reynolds in “Smokey and the Bandit” and Bo and Luke in “The Dukes of Hazzard” became the smiling standard-bearers of the New South, and the “Glen Campbell” who emerged in that era seemed almost too perfect a fit. In ads for his 1970 film “Norwood,” Campbell was saddled with the moniker “Goodtime Glen.”
Read more ▾
B. 1947
B. 1947
Joseph Nicolosi
His life traced the rise and fall of the ex-gay movement.
Dr. Joseph Nicolosi wouldn’t take gay for an answer.
It was 2012, and Alan Chambers, Nicolosi’s friend and a fellow leader in the ex-gay movement, was causing trouble by telling the truth. During speeches and television appearances, Chambers admitted that he was still attracted to men, that “99.9 percent” of people with unwanted same-sex attractions don’t change and that conversion therapy — sometimes called reparative therapy — is often psychologically harmful, particularly for teenagers.
Read more ▾
B. 1923
B. 1923
Roy Dotrice
The voice that brought the voices of Westeros to life in your head.
The experience of being read to, whether it’s toddlers nodding off to “Goodnight Moon” at bedtime or 19th-century families gathering to hear the latest serial installment of “Great Expectations,” is a deep-rooted element of a love for books. A reader’s performance can add further layers of artistry and meaning to a story, and because listeners have their hands and eyes free, they can do something useful while they listen. Being read to while washing dishes, shoveling snow or working out feels like a bonus, a book-lover’s exacta of pleasure and efficiency.
Audiobooks are the fastest-growing segment of the publishing industry, and the masterpiece of the form to date may well be Roy Dotrice’s reading of George R. R. Martin’s epic fantasy series, “A Song of Ice and Fire,” the source material for HBO’s “Game of Thrones.” The five audiobooks, totaling 201 hours, have all the strengths of Martin’s novels, which plumb the grim subjectivity of their many principal characters with patient thoroughness. And because you have approximately $11 trillion to spend on special effects in your mind’s eye, you can stage a spectacle in your head that puts to shame anything seen on a TV screen. Martin, who worked with Dotrice on the TV series “Beauty and the Beast,” recruited him to record his books because he recognized Dotrice’s voice as an instrument of sorcerous potency.
Read more ▾
B. 1943
B. 1943
Richard Benson
A selection of beloved objects from those we lost.
“You have to understand that he made things constantly. In the back shed, he made steam engines; in the basement, he had a woodshop and a metal shop. For 60 years, he was always making something. Steam engines were a fascination of his, and I haven’t a clue why. He was like a little kid: he always wanted to figure out the way things work, he always wanted to get to the bottom of things. He was very intellectual, but he did not want to talk intellectually about steam engines. He wanted to play with them.”Barbara Benson, wife
John Pilson is a photographer and filmmaker who is currently working on a video project titled “Parole Parole Parole.”
See more things they loved
B. 1937
B. 1937
Dennis Banks
A life caught between power and powerlessness.
Dennis Banks, whose Ojibwa (Chippewa) ancestors’ names were not registered on a ship’s manifest, was looking to put down roots. Born on a reservation in Minnesota, Banks was shipped off by the Bureau of Indian Affairs to a boarding school at age 5, the better to erase his heritage. When he returned home after 11 years, his mother had moved and started a new family.
In 1968, after a stint in the Air Force in Japan that ended with Banks going AWOL, and two and a half years in jail on a burglary rap, he helped found the American Indian Movement (AIM) to advance the interests of Native Americans.
Read more ▾
B. Before 1000
B. Before 1000
Pioneer Cabin Tree
When we can no longer pass through the giant sequoia.
The giant sequoia was made of more than a thousand years of light and air and rain and Sierra Nevada soil. It was a survivor. It endured the fire that hollowed its base, and a lightning strike that reduced its height to around 150 feet from between two and three hundred, and it lived on for more than a century after a tunnel was cut through it in the 1880s, though it was ravaged by decay. Eventually only a solitary branch bore leaves. But on Jan. 8, the Pioneer Cabin Tree was finally lost to a storm that pried its roots free of the earth. Photographs of the aftermath show split shards and lengths of rusty timber, scraps of torn foliage upon piles of earth and ice.
The Pioneer Cabin Tree may have been the most famous tree in Calaveras Big Trees State Park in Northern California. Once upon a time tourists carved upon its walls, punched their names into pieces of tin and nailed them inside. Vehicles and hikers made their way through it, posing for pictures. Its demise is the end of one more iconic tunnel tree, those peculiar artifacts of the 19th-century tourist trade.
Read more ▾
B. 1932
B. 1932
Dick Gregory
A selection of beloved objects from those we lost.
“He always had healing things with him. One time, we were on a trans-Atlantic flight in 1997, we were going to the African-American Leadership Summit in Harare, Zimbabwe, and we were traveling around with Ms. Coretta Scott King. She was in some kind of pain, and my father carried a small metal instrument — it was almost like an acupuncture tool. Everyone woke up in a panic because they smelled smoke on this chartered fight full of civil rights leaders! But that was him, healing through laughter or through his hands. He even ear-candled Muhammad Ali. Many times when people needed potions, lotions or tonics, they would call Dick Gregory. He would spend thousands of dollars at Whole Foods a week. He would be offended if you didn’t take it.”Christian Gregory, son
John Pilson is a photographer and filmmaker who is currently working on a video project titled “Parole Parole Parole.”
See more things they loved
Behind the Lens of The Things They Loved
The photographer explains how this year’s photo essay came together.
The Lives They Loved
As part of the magazine’s annual The Lives They Lived issue, we invited readers to contribute a photograph and a story of someone close to them who died this year.
John Pilson is a photographer and filmmaker who is currently working on a video project titled “Parole Parole Parole.”

text:
**Title: The High-Stakes Clash for the Soul of Climbing: Dominance and Resilience in the Vertical World**

**By [Your Name] | Date: October [Insert Date], 2023**

In the world of climbing, where physical prowess meets an almost spiritual connection to nature, an unexpected rift has developed between two titans of the sport. In a backdrop defined by sheer cliffs and rugged terrain, one climber's mettle has dramatically eclipsed his competitor, a rivalry that has captivated enthusiasts and reshaped the ethos of climbing.

### The Emergence of a Contender

At the crux of this narrative is Alex Johnson, a name that has resonated within climbing communities for over a decade. Johnson’s ascent in the sport has not only been marked by astonishing technical skill but also by his emphasis on inclusivity and the psychological aspects of climbing. Opposing him is Ryan McKenzie, a veteran climber whose traditional and aggressive approach has garnered both admiration and criticism. McKenzie, often seen on the podiums of prestigious competitions, has championed a "win at all costs" mentality that stands in stark contrast to Johnson’s philosophy.

### Prelude to Conflict

The friction between Johnson and McKenzie became evident during the recent climbers' summit, a gathering designed to promote fraternity among climbers while addressing pressing issues such as access to climbing areas and sustainability practices. As leaders of their respective factions, the two engaged in a spirited debate, highlighting the divide between those who view climbing as a competitive sport and others who regard it as an expression of individuality and connection with nature. The stakes were raised when both climbers committed to competing in the upcoming International Climbing Championship, set to take place in Sierra Nevada, a hallowed ground for climbers that has become a battleground for ideologies.

### The Climactic Showdown

As the championship approached, the mounting tension was palpable. Both climbers unleashed rigorous training regimes, each vying for supremacy not just on the walls but also in the hearts of fellow climbers. Johnson’s approach focused on innovative techniques and mental fortitude, while McKenzie emphasized brute strength and competitive aggression.

On the day of the competition, climbers and spectators alike flocked to the event, where sections of challenging routes were designed to test every facet of climbing acumen. McKenzie’s early lead sparked a wave of enthusiasm, but it was Johnson’s methodical approach and resilience that captivated the audience. With each bolt and hold, Johnson displayed not only technical mastery but also a deep respect for the mountain, eliciting cheers for his poise under pressure.

### The Turning Point

As the route neared its climax, it became clear that this was not just a competition of speed but a symbolic moment that would define the future of the sport. In a breathtaking display, Johnson not only matched McKenzie’s time but also demonstrated a climber's grace that transcended the competition. His ascent was emblematic of a growing movement within climbing that champions connection over competition—an “eraser” of the traditional tensions that McKenzie embodies.

The crowd erupted in applause as Johnson made his final reach for the summit. He stood atop the cliff, arms wide open, proclaiming a new era of climbing—a community-centric approach that embraces diversity, mental well-being, and environmental stewardship.

### Aftermath and Reflection

With Johnson’s victory, the implications ripple far beyond the championship title. He has emerged not just as a champion of the sport but as a leader advocating for a more inclusive climbing culture. McKenzie, graciously acknowledging Johnson’s triumph, has reconsidered his stance on competition, hinting at potential collaborations that may bridge the divide between their philosophies. 

As the dust settles from this climactic duel, the climbing community stands at a pivotal crossroads. Johnson’s victory not only marks a personal achievement but also signifies an evolving understanding of what it means to climb. In this battle for the soul of climbing, a new paradigm has emerged—one that values authenticity, resilience, and collective progress over individual glory.

### Conclusion

As climbing continues to grow in popularity and complexity, the dynamics among its leaders will shape its future. The confrontation between Johnson and McKenzie will undoubtedly be analyzed and debated for generations to come, serving as a reminder that even in the fiercest of competitions, the essence of climbing lies in the shared experiences that connect us all to the rock faces we love. 

**[End of Article]**

---

*Follow @NYTimes for more stories on sport and culture.*

Alzheimer’s Takes a Financial Toll Long Before Diagnosis, Study Finds
New research shows that people who develop dementia often begin falling behind on bills years earlier.
ByBen Casselman
Long before people develop dementia, they often begin falling behind on mortgage payments, credit card bills and other financial obligations, new research shows.
A team of economists and medical experts at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and Georgetown University combined Medicare records with data from Equifax, the credit bureau, tostudy how people’s borrowing behavior changedin the years before and after a diagnosis of Alzheimer’s or a similar disorder.
What they found was striking: Credit scores among people who later develop dementia begin falling sharply long before their disease is formally identified. A year before diagnosis, these people were 17.2 percent more likely to be delinquent on their mortgage payments than before the onset of the disease, and 34.3 percent more likely to be delinquent on their credit card bills. The issues start even earlier: The study finds evidence of people falling behind on their debts five years before diagnosis.
“The results are striking in both their clarity and their consistency,” said Carole Roan Gresenz, a Georgetown University economist who was one of the study’s authors. Credit scores and delinquencies, she said, “consistently worsen over time as diagnosis approaches, and so it literally mirrors the changes in cognitive decline that we’re observing.”
The research adds to agrowing body of workdocumenting what many Alzheimer’s patients and their families already know: Decision-making, including on financial matters, can begin to deteriorate long before a diagnosis is made or even suspected. People who are starting to experience cognitive decline may miss payments, make impulsive purchases or put money into risky investments they would not have considered before the disease.
“There’s not just getting forgetful, but our risk tolerance changes,” said Lauren Hersch Nicholas, a professor at the University of Colorado School of Medicine who hasstudied dementia’s impacton people’s finances. “It might seem suddenly like a good move to move a diversified financial portfolio into some stock that someone recommended.”
Tell us about your family's challenges with money management and Alzheimer's.

prompt: Alzheimer’s Takes a Financial Toll Long Before Diagnosis, Study Finds

text:
**Alzheimer’s Takes a Financial Toll Long Before Diagnosis, Study Finds**

*By [Author Name]*  
*Published: [Date]*  

In a startling revelation underscored by a recent study, researchers have found that the financial repercussions of Alzheimer’s disease often begin much earlier than the clinical diagnosis of the condition. The implications of these findings could reshape how caregivers, families, and health care systems address financial planning and support for those affected by Alzheimer’s and other forms of dementia.

**Understanding the Financial Impact**

The study, published in the *Journal of Alzheimer’s Disease*, tracked financial data from individuals who later received an Alzheimer’s diagnosis, comparing it with a control group without dementia. Researchers examined a range of financial indicators, including out-of-pocket medical expenses, income decline, and retirement savings depletion.

The analysis revealed that participants who went on to develop Alzheimer’s experienced a significant decrease in their financial health starting up to six years prior to their official diagnosis. Notably, their out-of-pocket medical expenses doubled, while income from employment decreased sharply as cognitive decline affected their ability to work.

**Key Findings**

1. **Increased Medical Expenses**: The study found that individuals with preclinical signs of Alzheimer’s had medical expenses that were 49% higher on average compared to their cognitively healthy peers. This rise in costs often included expenses related to diagnostic tests, doctor visits, and early treatments or interventions.

2. **Income Decline**: Participants showed a progressive decline in income, correlating with the onset of subtle cognitive symptoms. A significant 27% drop in income was noted in the years preceding the diagnosis, attributed largely to reduced work hours or early retirement driven by declining mental acuity.

3. **Retirement Savings Depletion**: Those nearing a diagnosis drained their savings at an alarming rate. On average, retirement savings diminished by up to 30%, with many participants forced to dip into their savings to cover both increased medical and everyday living expenses.

**Implications for Families and Caregivers**

The findings highlight the urgent need for families to engage in early financial planning in anticipation of Alzheimer’s-related costs. Dr. [First Last Name], a lead author of the study, stated, “Most families are unprepared for the financial burden that Alzheimer’s can impose, and our study emphasizes the importance of proactive financial management in the years leading up to a diagnosis.”

**Recommendations for Financial Planning**

Experts recommend several strategies for families navigating the financial implications of Alzheimer’s:

- **Early Assessment**: Regular assessments of both cognitive function and financial health can help families gauge risk and prepare adequately for potential challenges.
  
- **Advance Care Planning**: Establishing durable powers of attorney, wills, and health care proxies can safeguard against future uncertainties.
  
- **Financial Counseling**: Consulting financial advisors who specialize in elder care can provide families with tailored strategies to manage both short-term expenses and long-term savings.

**Conclusion**

As the incidence of Alzheimer’s continues to rise, understanding its financial implications is crucial for affected individuals and families. This study serves as a clarion call for early intervention—not just from a health perspective, but also regarding financial preparedness. By confronting the financial realities of Alzheimer’s head-on, families can better navigate the complex journey ahead.

For more information on managing Alzheimer’s-related expenses and resources available for affected families, please visit the *Alzheimer’s Association* website or consult a healthcare professional.  

---

prompt: Why does David Crystal believe the period, one of the oldest forms of punctuation, may be dying?

text:
### Is the Period Facing Extinction? Linguist David Crystal's Provocative Assessment

In an age where communication methods and styles are rapidly evolving, the iconic period—a punctuation mark steeped in history—faces an uncertain future. Renowned linguist David Crystal, who has extensively studied the evolution of language and communication, offers an intriguing perspective on this topic. He argues that the period, once considered essential for demarcating the end of a sentence, may be diminishing in relevance. Crystal's assertions raise important questions about the nature of modern communication and the implications for language as we know it.

#### The Historical Significance of the Period

The period has its roots in ancient writing systems and has played a crucial role in the development of written language. Its primary function is to signify the end of a declarative sentence, providing a clear stopping point for readers. This clarity has been pivotal in helping readers grasp the structure and meaning of written discourse. Yet, as Crystal points out, the way people communicate is transforming, thanks in large part to digital platforms that favor brevity and immediacy.

#### The Digital Age and Changing Communication Styles

The rise of texting, social media, and instant messaging has altered the landscape of communication. Crystal observes that these formats often encourage a more casual and rapid exchange of ideas, where the traditional rules of grammar and punctuation are frequently relaxed or ignored. The period, in particular, is often perceived as adding an unwanted formality to a conversation. As a result, many users opt for punctuation-free messages, leaving out the period altogether in favor of a more fluid style of communication.

Furthermore, the use of emojis and other visual aids has largely replaced the need for certain punctuation marks to convey tone or sentiment. A simple smiley face can express a sense of closure that a period once provided, leading to a shift in how people interpret the end of a statement.

#### The Impact of Language Evolution on the Period

Crystal emphasizes that language is not static; it is constantly evolving in response to changes in culture, technology, and social practices. While the decline of the period may seem alarming to traditionalists, Crystal argues that this phenomenon should be seen within the broader context of linguistic evolution. Just as languages have adapted over centuries to the needs of their speakers, so too is contemporary communication adapting to the preferences of digital natives.

The implications of this shift are profound. As younger generations gravitate toward more fluid, informal communication methods, the relevance of the period as a marker of sentence completion may continue to wane. Crystal asserts that this is not necessarily a decline in linguistic capability, but rather an evolution reflecting new communicative behaviors.

#### Conclusion: The Future of the Period

In conclusion, David Crystal's examination of the period invites reflection on how we communicate in the contemporary era. The potential decline of the period serves as a reminder that language is a living, breathing entity, constantly shaped by the contexts in which it is used. While the period may be losing its prominence in digital conversations, it is crucial to recognize that this evolution is part of a larger narrative about the dynamics of language and communication.

As we navigate an increasingly digital world, one must wonder: Will the period become an artifact of the past, or will it find a new role in the tapestry of modern expression? Only time will tell, but for now, the conversation is far from over.

Donald Trump Laments Loss of Aerosol Sprays to Frame His Hair
Donald J. Trump appears to be more concerned about the quality of his hair than the quality of the air.
Mr. Trump has offered little in the way of an environmental policy during his presidential campaign, but on Wednesday he said that President Obama’s concerns about the environment were infringing
                                                on his rights as a consumer. More pressing than saving the ozone layer, he suggested, was the freedom to buy aerosol hairspray.
“You can’t use hairspray because hairspray is going to affect the ozone,”Mr. Trump said during a rally in South Carolina.
                                                “They don’t want me to use hairspray, they want me to use the pump.”
Mr. Trump’s singular hairstyle has been the subject of widespread speculation over the years, and on Wednesday he made it clear that he gave considerable thought to maintaining his signature look.
Imitating the “bing, bing, bing” sound that his current hair product makes when he applies it with a pump, Mr. Trump revealed that he had a strong preference for old-fashioned aerosol sprays.
“It comes out in big globs, right, and it’s stuck in your hair and you say, ‘Oh my God, I’ve got to take a shower again, my hair is all screwed up,’” Mr. Trump lamented to
                                                a laughing audience.
Aerosol sprays were actually phased out in the United States in the 1990s, years before Mr. Obama was president, and the ban resulted from the Montreal Protocol in 1987, signed by President George H. W. Bush,
                                                which sought to curtail the damage aerosol products did to the disappearing ozone layer. Since then, the hairspray industry has been able to find substitutes that produce the same misty effect of CFCs and
                                                aerosol.
The Obama administration has made reducing carbon emissions a crucial part of its agenda to combat global warming. But Mr. Trump said that the president was a hypocrite on the issue because he flies around the
                                                world in the antiquated Air Force One, releasing harmful toxins.
For his part, Mr. Trump said that he did his spraying inside his well-sealed Manhattan penthouse, inflicting little damage on the atmosphere.
“I don’t think anything gets out,” Mr. Trump said of the pollutants he emits while taming his hair.
Coral Davenport contributed reporting.

prompt: Mr. Trump said that President Obama’s concerns about the environment were infringing on his rights as a consumer.

text:
**Title: Trump Defends Consumer Rights Amid Environmental Concerns Raised by Obama**

**By [Author’s Name]**  
**Date: [Insert Date]**  
**Location: Washington, D.C.**

In a recent statement, former President Donald Trump addressed concerns raised by President Barack Obama regarding environmental regulations, asserting that such measures infringe upon individual rights, particularly those of consumers. This declaration has reignited the longstanding debate between economic development and environmental stewardship in American politics.

### The Context of Trump’s Comments

During a rally in [Location], Trump remarked, "President Obama’s environmental regulations are a direct attack on your rights as a consumer. They limit choices, raise costs, and hurt working families." This statement reflects Trump's ongoing stance against what he perceives as overregulation, a theme he prominently featured during his presidency.

Trump's comments come in the wake of Obama's recent remarks at a climate summit, where he emphasized the urgent need for stronger environmental protection measures to combat climate change. Obama criticized past and present leaders who push back against these regulations, arguing that environmental health is linked to the socio-economic well-being of all citizens.

### Clash of Ideologies

This rhetorical clash highlights a fundamental ideological divide in American governance. Supporters of Trump's viewpoint argue that excessive environmental regulations stifle economic growth and limit free market options for consumers. They contend that businesses should have the freedom to operate without stringent government oversight, which they assert can lead to innovation and job creation.

Conversely, environmental advocates, including Obama, argue that sustainable practices are essential to secure a livable future. They maintain that environmental degradation disproportionately affects disadvantaged communities and that regulatory frameworks are crucial for ensuring public health and safety.

### Implications for Policy and Politics

Trump's challenge to Obama's environmental advocacy signals a potential rallying point for right-leaning voters concerned about their consumer freedoms. As the 2024 presidential campaign heats up, environmental policies are likely to be a significant topic, with candidates poised to either support or dismantle existing regulations based on their message.

Critics of Trump argue that prioritizing consumer rights over environmental protection could lead to a regression in climate action, potentially exacerbating issues such as air and water pollution and contributing to the global climate crisis. Studies have shown that environmental regulations can lead to long-term economic benefits by fostering sustainable industries and protecting natural resources.

### A Growing Conversation

As both parties prepare for the upcoming election, the balance between protecting consumer rights and ensuring environmental sustainability remains a pivotal issue that resonates with a broad segment of the American populace. Engaging in this conversation is critical, as voters seek to understand the implications of each candidate's policies on their daily lives and future prospects.

In a world increasingly aware of climate change challenges, the discourse surrounding consumer rights versus environmental protections is likely to evolve further. The question remains whether leaders can effectively reconcile these two important priorities for a sustainable future.

### Conclusion

Trump's assertion that environmental regulations infringe upon consumer rights reflects a deeper ideological debate in America about the role of government in regulating industry and protecting the environment. As political leaders navigate this intricate landscape, the dialogue will shape not only the immediate electoral landscape but also the legacy of environmental policy in the United States.

**For more coverage on environmental issues and political discourse, follow [@NYTimes] on Twitter.**  

---  

**[End of Article]**

Audra McDonald,the star of one of this theatrical season’s most-anticipated musicals, will miss three

Ms. McDonald, who has won a record six Tony Awards, is to play the actress Lottie Gee in “Shuffle Along, Or, The Making of the Musical Sensation of 1921 and All That Followed.” The show is scheduled to

**New York, NY** — In a surprising announcement that has left fans and theater enthusiasts buzzing, a six-time Tony Award-winning actor has confirmed they will not participate in the upcoming production of *[Show Title]*, citing a "pre-existing commitment." According to a statement released by the show's publicist, this decision comes after much anticipation surrounding the actor's involvement.

## A Noteworthy Career

The celebrated performer, who has captivated audiences on Broadway and beyond, was set to take on a pivotal role in the highly anticipated production. Renowned for their versatility and emotional depth, the actor has received critical acclaim for performances in a range of genres, from musicals to straight plays, earning their six Tony Awards across various categories.

## Details of the Show

*Show Title*, directed by [Director’s Name], aims to bring a fresh perspective to classic storytelling. The production, which is set to premiere on [Premiere Date], has generated significant buzz due to its star-studded cast and innovative direction. The theater community had particularly excited about the actor’s role, believing their presence would add a compelling dynamic to the performance.

## The Publicist's Statement

In a formal statement, the publicist explained, "Due to a pre-existing commitment, [Actor’s Name] will not be joining the cast of *Show Title*. We respect their decision and look forward to announcing a suitable replacement soon." No further details regarding the nature of the actor's prior engagement have been disclosed.

## Reactions from Fans and Colleagues

Following the announcement, fans took to social media to express their disappointment, with many sharing a mixture of surprise and support for the actor's decision. Colleagues from the theater community also weighed in, with several expressing admiration for the actor's previous work and wishing them success in their ongoing projects.

## Looking Ahead

text:
# Solve the Puzzle: A Journey into the World of Problem-Solving

## Introduction

In an era dominated by rapid technological advancements and complex challenges, the art of problem-solving has never been more critical. From everyday conundrums to intricate global issues, the ability to solve puzzles—whether mathematical, logical, or situational—plays a crucial role in our personal and professional lives. This article delves into the intricacies of problem-solving, its significance, various methodologies, and how anyone can hone this essential skill.

## The Significance of Problem-Solving

Problem-solving skills are foundational to both individual growth and societal progress. In a world rife with uncertainties, the capability to tackle issues effectively can lead to innovation and resilience. Notably, businesses that foster a problem-solving culture tend to experience higher productivity and employee satisfaction. Moreover, individuals equipped with these skills can navigate life’s challenges with greater confidence, leading to improved mental health and overall well-being.

## Understanding the Puzzle

At its core, a puzzle, in the context of problem-solving, represents a situation or challenge that requires a solution. These can take various forms:

1. **Mathematical Puzzles:** These challenges often rely on logical reasoning and numerical skills.
2. **Logical Puzzles:** These involve reasoning to deduce a conclusion, frequently presented in the form of riddles.
3. **Situational Puzzles:** These pertain to real-life scenarios requiring critical thinking and strategic planning to resolve.

Each type of puzzle caters to different cognitive abilities, illustrating the diverse nature of problem-solving.

## Methodologies to Solve Puzzles

The process of solving puzzles can be broken down into several structured methodologies:

### 1. Define the Problem
Understanding the exact nature of the problem is paramount. This step involves identifying the core issue, its context, and the factors influencing it.

### 2. Gather Information
Research and data collection are essential. In this phase, one should seek input from various sources, ensuring a comprehensive understanding of the puzzle at hand.

### 3. Generate Options
Brainstorming multiple potential solutions fosters creativity. Encourage thinking outside the box, as this can often lead to innovative approaches.

### 4. Evaluate Options
Critical evaluation of each possibility is necessary. Assess the pros and cons, potential risks, and feasibility of implementation.

### 5. Implement the Solution
Once a viable solution is identified, it is time to put it into action. This may involve strategic planning and mobilizing resources.

### 6. Reflect and Adjust
Post-implementation, it's vital to reflect on the effectiveness of the solution. Analyzing outcomes allows for adjustments and improvements for future problem-solving endeavors.

## Engaging with Puzzles

To sharpen problem-solving skills, engaging with various types of puzzles can be highly beneficial:

- **Crossword Puzzles** enhance vocabulary and lateral thinking.
- **Sudoku** boosts logical reasoning and pattern recognition.
- **Escape Rooms** foster teamwork and strategic planning.

Incorporating these activities into one’s routine can cultivate a mindset conducive to effective problem-solving.

## Conclusion

The ability to solve puzzles effectively is an invaluable asset in both personal and professional spheres. By employing structured methodologies and engaging with diverse problem types, individuals can enhance their cognitive skills and adapt to challenges with greater ease. In a rapidly evolving world, mastering the art of problem-solving may well be the key to unlocking opportunities and driving progress.

## Call to Action

As we navigate an increasingly complex landscape, consider how you can sharpen your problem-solving skills. Engage with puzzles regularly, embrace challenges, and foster a mindset of creativity and resilience. If you’d like to share your thoughts on this important skill, join the conversation on Twitter with the hashtag #SolveThePuzzle.

--- 

For more insights and articles, visit [NY Times](http://nytimes.com).
label: ai
prompt: Solve the Puzzle

Auto Safety Regulator Investigating Tesla Recall of Autopilot
The National Highway Safety Administration also released an analysis of crashes involving the system that showed at least 29 fatal accidents over five and a half years.
ByJ. Edward Moreno
The federal government’s main auto safety agency said on Friday that it was investigating Tesla’s recall of its Autopilot driver-assistance system because regulators were concerned that the company had not done enough to ensure that drivers remained attentive while using the technology.
The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said in documents posted on its website that it was looking into Tesla’srecallin December of two million vehicles, which covered nearly all of the cars the company had manufactured in the United States since 2012. The safety agency said it had concerns about crashes that took place after the recall and results from preliminary tests of recalled vehicles.
The agency also published an analysis that found that there had beenat least 29 fatal accidentsinvolving Autopilot and a more advanced system that Tesla calls Full Self-Driving from January 2018 to August 2023. In 13 of those fatal accidents, the fronts of Teslas hit objects or people in their path.
The investigation of Tesla’s recall and the new data about crashes adds to a list of headaches for Tesla, the dominant electric-vehicle maker in the United States. The company’s sales in the first three months of the year fell more than 8 percent from a year earlier, the first such drop since the early days of the coronavirus pandemic.
Tesla announced in December that it would recall its Autopilot software after an investigation by the auto safety agency found that the carmaker hadn’t put in place enough safeguards to make sure the system, which can accelerate, brake and control cars in other ways, was used safely by drivers who were supposed to be ready at any moment to retake control of their cars using Autopilot.
In its analysis of Tesla crash data, the safety agency found that when the company’s cameras, sensors and software did not spot obstacles in the car’s path and drivers did not compensate for that failure quickly enough the consequences were often catastrophic.

text:
**Title: Auto Safety Regulator Investigates Tesla’s Autopilot Recall**

**Subtitle: Federal Review Underlines Ongoing Concerns About Autonomous Driving Technologies**

**By: [Your Name]  
Date: October 23, 2023**

In a significant development for the automotive industry, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has launched an investigation into Tesla’s recent recall related to its Autopilot system. This move highlights escalating scrutiny over the safety of automated driving technologies as the demand for advanced driver-assistance systems continues to grow.

### Background on the Recall

Tesla announced a recall affecting approximately 320,000 vehicles equipped with its Autopilot system, which is marketed as an advanced driver-assistance feature that allows cars to steer, accelerate, and brake automatically within certain conditions. The recall was prompted by concerns that certain versions of the software could misinterpret road conditions and fail to respond appropriately, posing risks to drivers and pedestrians alike.

This is not the first time Tesla has faced scrutiny over its Autopilot features. Previous investigations have examined several high-profile accidents involving Tesla vehicles operating under Autopilot, raising questions about the reliability of the technology and the adequacy of driver supervision.

### NHTSA’s Investigation

The NHTSA’s investigation will assess whether Tesla’s Autopilot system adequately complies with federal safety regulations and whether the recall was sufficient to address known defects in the system. The agency’s review will focus on:

1. **Software Integrity**: Analyzing the functionality of the software that controls the Autopilot feature and determining if its operational parameters are safe.
  
2. **Driver Notification**: Evaluating how well Tesla communicated the recall to affected vehicle owners, including the effectiveness of the notifications and urgency of the required updates.

3. **Previous Complaints**: Investigating any correlations between prior complaints or accidents involving Tesla's Autopilot and the current recall.

### Industry Response and Implications

The investigation has elicited mixed reactions from the automotive industry and consumer advocacy groups. Critics assert that the recall is a symptom of Tesla’s aggressive push toward fully autonomous vehicles without sufficient safety safeguards. “Software bugs in critical driving systems can have catastrophic consequences,” said John Smith, a safety expert at the Consumer Federation of America. “The industry must prioritize safety over speed.”

On the other hand, proponents argue that Tesla is being unfairly targeted. They posit that the continuous updates to Autopilot are part of a rapidly evolving technology, and that many other manufacturers are also grappling with similar challenges in their driving assistance systems.

### Moving Forward

The NHTSA’s investigation is poised to set important precedents for the regulation of autonomous driving technologies. With the agency already ramping up oversight, the outcomes of this probe may influence future regulatory frameworks across the industry. 

As part of the ongoing examination, Tesla has committed to cooperating fully with the NHTSA. The company reiterated its dedication to safety and innovation through a public statement emphasizing that recalls are a standard aspect of vehicle manufacturing that underscores its commitment to consumer safety.

### Conclusion

As Tesla navigates this investigation, the recall of its Autopilot system serves as a critical juncture for both the company and the auto industry at large. With the rapid advancement of autonomous technologies, the need for robust safety measures and regulatory oversight has never been more pressing. Stakeholders will be closely watching how this situation unfolds, as it may greatly impact consumer confidence in autonomous driving systems and the future of vehicle automation.

**[End of Article]**

---

- “NHTSA investigates Tesla’s recall involving Autopilot, raising alarms about the safety of autonomous driving tech. Is the industry ready for stronger regulations?” #Tesla #Autopilot #AutoSafety

text:
**Title: Representative Dan Crenshaw Emphasizes American Heroism at the Republican National Convention**

*Date: [Insert Date]*  
*By: [Insert Author Name]*

In a stirring address during the Republican National Convention, Representative Dan Crenshaw of Texas captured the attention of attendees and viewers alike with a compelling narrative of American heroism, drawing from his experiences as a Navy SEAL in Afghanistan. The speech resonated deeply with the themes of sacrifice, resilience, and patriotism, reflecting a pivotal moment in Crenshaw’s political journey and the larger national discourse.

**Opening Remarks: A Personal Journey**

Kicking off his address, Crenshaw recounted his journey from the battlefield to Congress, sharing poignant anecdotes from his time in Afghanistan. The Congressman, who lost an eye during a deployment, recounted the harrowing moments of combat that tested not only his physical limits but also his spirit. His unyielding commitment to serving his country emerged as a central theme, inviting the audience to reflect on the sacrifices made by millions of American service members.

**The Essence of Heroism**

Crenshaw's speech painted a vivid picture of what it means to be a hero in today’s America. He defined heroism not solely in terms of battlefield valor, but as a composite of courage, bravery, and the willingness to confront adversity head-on. Citing various examples from military history, he implored listeners to recognize everyday acts of heroism among civilians—first responders, healthcare workers, and community leaders—who embody the spirit of resilience.

“Heroism isn’t just about wearing a uniform; it’s about the spirit that lies within each of us,” Crenshaw declared, challenging the audience to adopt this mindset in their daily lives. As he spoke, attendees were seen nodding in agreement, inspired by his message of inclusive heroism.

**Lessons from the Front Lines**

Crenshaw interwove his military experiences with the current political climate, arguing that the same resolve exemplified by service members should guide American citizens in the face of modern challenges. He underscored that the lessons learned in combat—the need for unity, trust, and determination—are equally relevant in political discourse.

Drawing parallels between the challenges faced in Afghanistan and the struggles Americans endure today, he urged unity across partisan lines. "We are all on the same team," he stated, emphasizing the need for collaboration and mutual respect. The audience erupted in applause, resonating with his call for unity amid a climate of divisiveness.

**A Tribute to the Fallen**

As Crenshaw concluded his speech, he paid tribute to fallen heroes, reminding attendees of the ultimate sacrifices made by numerous soldiers. He highlighted the importance of remembering and honoring their legacies, reaffirming the idea that true heroism endures beyond the battlefield.

“Let us strive to be worthy of their sacrifices. Let us fight for the principles they stood for—freedom, justice, and the American way of life,” he implored, leaving the audience with stirring images of valor and patriotism.

**A Lasting Impact**

Crenshaw’s speech at the Republican National Convention not only resonated with party members but also with a broader audience eager for messages of hope and strength. His articulation of American heroism, rooted in personal experience and collective values, reinforced his position as a prominent voice within the Republican Party.

As the convention unfolds, Crenshaw's address stands as a reminder of the enduring power of heroism in shaping American identity—both on and off the battlefield. The Congressman’s compelling narrative of sacrifice and resilience promises to echo in the hearts and minds of constituents long after the final gavel falls.

*For more updates on the Republican National Convention and its speakers, follow [Insert Social Media Links].*

text:
### Thousands Compete as Boston Marathon Returns After Pandemic Hiatus

**Boston, MA –** After a year of uncertainty and forced silence, the Boston Marathon roared back to life on Monday, October 11, 2021, with thousands of dedicated runners lining up to reclaim their space on the historic 26.2-mile course. The prestigious race, renowned as one of the oldest marathons in the world, had been paused in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, marking a significant interruption in its rich history.

#### A Triumphant Return

The 125th edition of the Boston Marathon was not only a return to form but also a triumphant moment for runners around the globe, many of whom had trained diligently for years in hopes of competing. Organizers reported over 20,000 registered participants, a stark contrast to the 5,000 who raced virtually in 2020. 

The air was electric with anticipation as the traditional early morning start featured the long-awaited sound of the starting gun echoing through the streets of Hopkinton. Runners, clad in various attire representing their countries and affiliated clubs, embarked on the iconic journey, with spectators lining the routes, cheering for their favorites and celebrating the resilience of the human spirit.

#### Health and Safety Measures

In consideration of ongoing health concerns, race officials implemented a series of health and safety measures to ensure the well-being of participants and spectators alike. Mandatory vaccinations or a negative COVID-19 test were required for all runners, and face coverings were recommended at the starting area. These precautions aimed not only to provide a safe running environment but also to restore confidence in large-scale sporting events.

#### Competitive Spirit and Personal Stories

Among the sea of runners was a diverse mix that showcased various stories of perseverance and ambition. Elite athletes, including defending champions and rising stars, competed for the coveted title, while weekend warriors represented their personal quests for fitness, completion, and sometimes, healing. 

Many participants used the marathon as an opportunity to raise awareness for charitable causes, with fundraising efforts aimed at local and national non-profits. Stories of triumph emerged as runners completed their journeys, sharing their emotional experiences on social media platforms.

#### A Look Ahead

As the race concluded, the sense of joy and accomplishment permeated the atmosphere. The successful execution of the 2021 Boston Marathon served as a beacon of hope for future events, signaling a possible return to normalcy in the sporting world. Organizers expressed their gratitude to the community for their continued support, emphasizing the marathon's role as not only an athletic competition but also a cherished tradition that unites people from all walks of life.

The Boston Marathon remains an emblem of resilience, and with the successful return this year, countless runners and fans have rekindled their love for the event that forever holds a significant place in the annals of running history. As we look to the future, the marathon's legacy continues to inspire, reminding us of the enduring power of determination and community. 

### Conclusion

The Boston Marathon’s revival after its pandemic-induced hiatus has not only reignited the passion for running but has also reaffirmed the collective resolve of the community to come together, celebrate, and overcome adversity. The race's successful return set the stage for many more memorable marathons to come, reminding us that every finish line crossed is a testament to the human spirit.

text:
**Title: Celebrated Observer of Urban Life: Mr. Stettner Dies at 93**

**By [Your Name]**

**Date: [Insert Date]**

Mr. Stettner, the distinguished artist and chronicler of life in New York and Paris, passed away on Thursday at the age of 93. Renowned for his keen observations and profound understanding of the human experience in these two vibrant cities, Stettner's work illuminated the spirit of urban life, earning him a cherished place in both art and literature.

**The Duality of His Cities**

Born in 1930 in New York City, Stettner often referred to New York and Paris as his “spiritual mothers.” His upbringing in the bustling streets of Manhattan deeply influenced his artistic vision. He later spent a significant portion of his life in the French capital, where he absorbed its rich culture and bohemian spirit. "These cities are alive in ways that words cannot capture," Stettner once said, encapsulating his philosophy that art should mirror the rhythm and chaos of urban life.

**Career Beginnings and Artistic Evolution**

Stettner’s early career was marked by a series of poignant illustrations and essays that captured everyday moments, from subway rides to quiet afternoons in Parisian cafés. His ability to depict the essence of city life garnered attention, leading to a burgeoning career that spanned decades. He published multiple volumes of poetry and prose, alongside a series of famed art exhibitions that showcased his unique interpretations of urban environments.

“Every corner of New York and Paris tells a story,” he said, often finding beauty in the mundane—whether it was a fleeting glance between strangers or a street vendor hawking wares. This narrative approach became a hallmark of his style, making his work accessible and relatable.

**Recognition and Influence**

Stettner’s contributions to the arts were recognized at numerous exhibitions, where he received accolades for his incisive portrayals of life in the two cities he loved. His collections often explore themes of identity, belonging, and the transformative power of place. Critics praised him for his ability to merge various artistic mediums, blending visual art with literary expression in a way that resonated with a broad audience.

In the 1980s, Stettner was awarded the prestigious *Grand Prix de la Ville de Paris*, highlighting his impact on the cultural discourse surrounding urban life. He continued to inspire generations of artists, writers, and thinkers who shared his passion for storytelling through observation.

**Legacy of the Urban Observer**

Mr. Stettner’s enduring legacy lies not just in his art, but in his philosophy regarding the impermanence of city life. "Cities are living organisms," he wrote in his memoirs. "They breathe, they grow, and they change. To capture that is to capture life itself." This perspective challenged contemporaries to seek deeper narratives in the world around them, encouraging them to look beyond the surface.

As tributes pour in from admirers and fellow artists, it is clear that Stettner's work will continue to resonate in the artistic community and beyond. His unerring eye for detail and profound love for New York and Paris have left an indelible mark on the cultural tapestry of both cities.

**Conclusion**

Mr. Stettner's passing is a significant loss to the artistic community, but his voice and vision will endure through the art and literature he created. He will be remembered not only for his remarkable talent but also for his unwavering commitment to capturing the essence of life in two of the world's greatest cities. In his own words, “Art is the window through which we can glimpse the soul of our cities,” a sentiment he embodied throughout his remarkable life.

**[Insert any related images or links to exhibitions and works by Mr. Stettner]**

Soumya Karlamangla, who writes The Times’s California newsletter, wants to balance uplifting stories and hard news happening in the Golden State.
ByJosh Ocampo
Times Insiderexplains who we are and what we do and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
When Soumya Karlamangla, who lives in San Francisco, tells someone she works for The New York Times, the reaction is often the same: a look of confusion.
“People that I’m interviewing in the field will say, ‘Oh, they flew you out here for this?’” she said in a recent conversation. “I usually tell them that there’s a good number of Times reporters in California. We have two bureaus.”
Ms. Karlamangla, who writes theCalifornia Todaynewsletter, joined The Times in July 2021 from The Los Angeles Times, where she covered health care news.
“I was tired of writing about Covid-19,” she said. When The Times approached her with an opportunity to cover news in the Golden State, she didn’t hesitate.
Ms. Karlamangla grew up in a suburb of Los Angeles, where she moved from the Midwest when she was 4. Now living in the Richmond neighborhood of San Francisco, she finds much of her inspiration for the newsletter, which publishes every weekday, in her surroundings. Last year, for example, she observed a number of Burmese restaurants in her neighborhood andwrote about the rise of the cuisine. She recently reported on howCalifornia got its name, answering a question she’d long had.
In a phone interview, Ms. Karlamangla shared her favorite part about reporting from California and her pursuit to report from all 58 of its counties. The conversation below has been edited and condensed.
